39071736.review:
Do not be fooled by the small playtime associated with my Steam account. I've played countless hours into this game. 

Due to this game being an old one a few might be put off by it's graphics the fanbase is quite active over on TTLG where patches and mods etc are constantly being worked on. However I would really suggest you play it vanilla first just to really get that retro feel if graphics don't bother you. 

If you're looking for the literal grandfather of the stealth genre you've found it. Not to be fooled by that modern reboot crap made by Eidos Montreal. 

A game where you the player are thrown into huge multiple levels and left to your own devices after a short training mission, there's no handholding here no big pointy arrows or minimaps or ability to take on multipe guards at once you are a thief not a fighter and this is really emphasised through your character's physical weakness. So if you're a fan of hardcore stealth where any moment's detection could mean your last this is for you. See Thief as a trilogy allows the player to live this power fantasy usually gotten from video games in this case by allowing the player to be somewhere they're not supposed to be and doing something they shouldn't which by not getting caught in the process allows them to feel so much more powerful over their enemies.

Thief 2: The Metal Age basically improves upon many of the flaws found within Thief: The Dark Project. If you like me were first put off by The Dark Project's focus upon the supernatural and magic, then Thief 2 is for you. This game retracts back from The Dark Project's more labyrinthine level design but mind you that does not mean the scale of the levels within this product have been reduced in fact some of the missions I've come across in this game really make me wonder what the hell has gone wrong with the industry nowadays. For a game released back in the good old year 2000 I would never have expected to be breaking into three-floor banks with a whole network of tunnels to be found underneath, to buildings which are roughly 6-7 floors in scale as well as to have a whole sequence beforehand set on the rooftops of a steampunk dsytopian city in which I the player can eavesdrop and break into these buildings, hear guards argue across the streets to one another as well as witness another group of thieves taking goods from another house which yes being the master thief that I am I pilfer their goods without them noticing. Which may I add is all completely optional, the sheer volume of methods in which you can tackle your objectives as well as explore the world is quite astonishing and in retrospect a player can really see how Looking Glass studios as a company was well ahead of its time.

Cutscenes are the most beautiful and original concept I've seen and I've yet still to this day to find a game that hits the same level of atmosphere through design as found within the works produced by the team at Looking Glass in which through the style of rotoscoping some of their cutscenes where others are just narration over still images allows the artstyle of this game to really blend with the physical game itself through both shape and tone intertwining the overall Gothic/steampunk direction the sequel took. 

Soundtrack which is done by Eric Brosius is really something else which words cannot describe, the game is worth buying for it's soundtrack and sound design alone which still to this day not one single stealth game has for some reason nailed one of the most simplisitic sound design choices that Thief introduced to gaming; the ability to listen and hear your enemy approaching the same way in which Thief conveys.

It's a game you've got to at least try for a few missions to get into its very unforgiving and this can put some people off but stick through it and I guarantee you this will be one of the top games you've played.

38861079.review:
So, Thief 2 is weird. Apart from some minor tweeks, The Metal Age is not that different from it's predecessor: it's basically the same thing, only with robots instead of zombies (which are equally as terrifying, don't get me wrong). 
Now, Karras' machines are quite dumb, easy to kill and easier to sneak past but if they spot you, you are good as dead, babe. This means that the game focuses much more on ghosting this time around, going as far as giving your a couple of missions in which sneaking past every enemy without interacting with them is one of the objectives required to beat the level.

In Thief 2 there are many more enemies, more convoluted puzzles, more branching paths and it is overal more criptic and harder than the first game but you also have more gadgets to help you along the way: Invisibility potions, slow-fall potions, Noisemaker arrows that actually work, exploding frog eggs that I've never used once and my absolute favourite: water arrows. I know they're not new to the series by any means but if you start a level and you buy anything but water arrows you're an idiot OR a masochist. Also I feel like they should have used Garrett's fancy mechanic eye a bit more. It smells like wasted opportunity right there, even because it was Karras himself, the main antagonist, to design it. It could have been a strong plot point and a great way to renovate the old game mechanics but instead it's just kind of there.

The graphics are improved a bit, still not that great but, I mean, for the time they were decent. Again the maps are incredibly large, labyrinthic and detaled so that's understandable but what I find inexcusable though is how repetitive the level design is. In the first game every level was memorable and unforgetable but here they are all kind of mhe, a part from a couple of exceptions ("Life of the party" is just fantastic). 
I feel that the problem here is that they went for a more geometric and specular design. Every corridor looks the same, every room has the same props in the same places so yes, you get lost easily, which is good in a thief game, but it's just not fun in this one in particular. Maybe this is the reason why they decided to include a marker on the in-game map that tells you where you are, I don't know but I'm really glad they did. It totally makes the "notes" feature useless but at least the game is playable like that.

The plot is, well, good? It's quite an intricate story and I think it needed a bit more breathing space: it starts too late into the game, so it gets rushed near the end. The plot itself is not bad at all, it's probably even better than the original's, I just feel it could have been told better. 

In conclusion, Thief II: The Metal Age is not as good as the original but it's still worth playing! The subtlety, the creepy atmosphere, the ingenious puzzling, the great voice acting, the amazing sound design, it's all still there, it's just a bit lazier this time. I know that you shouldn't fix what's not broken in the first place but still, this game could have been so much more!
If you like the original Thief you'll like this one too, that's for sure and if you're into modding as well, then you may want to explore the modding community that this game has: it's huge.

38705277.review:
Das Spiel war sehr gut und ist immer noch gut.

Das Spiel aus dem Jahr 2000 ist der zweite Teil der Thief-Serie. Die Serie habe ich früher abseits von Steam gespielt.

Zur Orientierung: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198063825413/recommended/211600/]Teil 1[/url] heißt im Original Thief: The Dark Project, im Deutschen Dark Project: Der Meisterdieb, wird - wohl überarbeitet - nun als Thief Gold vermarktet, und ist technisch ähnlich dem Teil 2 hier, der im Deutschen Dark Project 2: The Metal Age heißt. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198063825413/recommended/6980/]Teil 3[/url], der einheitlich Thief: Deadly Shadows heißt, ist technisch merklich verändert. Thief (2014) ist ein später Reboot der Serie. Seitdem kam nichts mehr.

In diesem Klassiker des Stealth spielen wir (wieder) den Meisterdieb Garrett (meist in First Person). Garrett ist ein zynischer und mysteriöser Antiheld, der in der Computerspielgeschichte einen hohen Rang einnimmt.

Garret agiert diesmal in der durch Steampunk geprägten mittelalterlich-viktorianischen Stadt, die schlicht City heißt. Er deckt eine Verschwörung auf, die die Bewohner in geistlose Sklaven ("Servants") verwandeln soll. Daneben betätigt er sich eifrig als Meisterdieb.

Das Spiel ist deutlich umfangreicher als Teil 1 mit großen und detailreicheren Leveln.

Das Gameplay fand ich beim ersten Mal, als ich es gespielt habe, sehr spannend. Es ist ein typisches Stealth-Spiel. Vorzugsweise versucht man, seine Ziele zu erreichen, ohne viel Aufmerksamkeit zu erregen. Daher schleicht man gerne, löscht Lichter und bleibt im Schatten. Man kann an den Wachen oft vorbeischleichen, manchmal ist es aber auch Teil der Mission, sie auszuknocken.

Die Ziele sind zu Beginn eines jeden der 15 Levels angegeben, können sich aber aus aktuellem Anlass auch mal ändern, was immer mitgeteilt wird. Man kann jederzeit nachschauen, was noch zu tun ist.

Ein offener Kampf mit einem Gegner ist entsprechend dem Stealth-Charakter des Spieles schwer und sollte vermieden werden. Man sollte immer vorsichtig zu Werke gehen. Dazu hat Garrett auch moderne Hilfsmittel wie die einer werfbaren Kamera, um die Gegend zu beobachten.

Mit ansteigendem Schwierigkeitsgrad ist es zudem gar nicht erlaubt, Gegner zu töten. Ausknocken geht aber, dazu hat er einen Schlagstock. Pfeile diene dazu, Lichter zu löschen, Wachen abzulenken oder durch Moos die Schritte zu dämpfen.

Die Vielfalt an Möglichkeiten, ans Ziel zu kommen, hat mir sehr gut gefallen.

Es gibt viele Objekte als Beute, Teils sehr gut als Secret versteckt, so dass man je nach Ehrgeiz ziemlich beschäftigt sein kann.

Es gibt drei verschiedene Schwierigkeitsgrade, die man zu Beginn jedes Levels einstellen kann. Dadurch werden die Gegner hell-/schwerhöriger und die Missionsziele werden erschwert/erleichtert.

Viel Speichern sollte und kann man, denn manchmal wird man auch mal von einer Wache hinter einer Tür oder ähnliches einfach überrascht oder man wird entdeckt, obwohl man sich doch so schön versteckt hat.

Die Grafik ist für das Erscheinungsjahr 2000, ganz in Ordnung. Dem Gameplay tut es nur wenig Abbruch. Interaktive Objekte werden (etwas übertrieben) erhellt dargestellt, was das Gameplay vereinfacht.

Der Sound ist auch passabel. Manchmal erzählt Garrett in einem inneren Monolog. Oft gibt es stimmungsvolle Hintergrundmusik. Die Geräusche sind auch OK.

Die Steuerung ist mit Tastatur/Maus ist in Ordnung. Man kann die Belegung auch ändern.

Ich hatte keine technischen Schwierigkeiten, das Spiel unter Windows 10 zu spielen.

Pro & Contra:

+ Sehr schönes Stealth-Abenteuer
+ Alternative Vorgehendweisen möglich
+ Relativ gute Geschichte
+ Verschiedene Schwierigkeitsgrade

o Grafik ist OK (damals gut, aus heutiger Sicht geht sie noch)


Wertung: 10/10 (damals), 8/10 (heute)

Das Spiel hat mir damals überaus gut gefallen. Einen Neudurchgang möchte ich durchaus nochmal machen. Für einen Stealth-Fan ist es trotz altersbedingter Abstriche immer noch zu empfehlen.

2 years after coming out with the great first game "Thief: The Dark Project" Looking Glass had decided to take another try on this brilliant stealth series. But not before they do a different type of game which was "System Shock 2" a sci-fi, horror, sort of rpg type game. It was good in it's own right, but during that process it seems they may have forgotten some of what made the first Thief game good. Also to clarify this is more or less the same time period as the first game. 

First of all the simple stuff, in the 2nd game we still have the great drawn art style for most of the cutscenes and we still have the store and briefing intros, we also still got Garrets great voice and personality. However the level design, atmosphere, and enemies (for the most part have changed). In the first game you had a mysterious, sometimes horror, sometimes just cold and lonely, sometimes funny atmosphere all at the sametime. The pagan factions and their creatures really brought a unique feel to the game. However in this one, it will feel much more generic where you only have normal guards and robots. The fantasy element and mysterious part of the world is almost completely gone. Now it feels much more like System Shock 2 rather than Thief. In fact many of the new enemies are just re-used and re-skinned assets from System Shock, which is just lazy. Another change to the gameplay is that the levels are GIGANTIC, some levels easily overstay their, welcome, either having their best parts at first or at the end, but some will easily feel like a slog, even if you are liking it, you will find yourself saying is it over yet? This gets worse in a game series that already was balanced perfectly now has random robots all over the place and cameras! So now you have to worry about that while there is so many more guards than there should be walking around. Because it's not just the size, it's the amount of stuff in it. So many more enemies that it begins to force you to play a certain way rather than thinking things out. Not too mention instead of using a great mixture of how the sound works with different floors, so many areas and levels have nothing but marble floors which are so loud that you end up having to either waste money on so many moss arrows or you have to cheat and do the thing where you barely tap the keys to move in half animation to make no sound. Big levels are great but not so big they feel bloated. They even admitted to wanting to make it bigger and tougher but this isnt how they should've. They honestly should have made their AI better, but this is something all companies do even now, make the game artificially harder rather than fixing their braindead and limited AI. However i will say the levels still have the great art style and look from the first game and thankfully they did find a way to push the engine to be able to allow them to correctly furnish the rooms, house and banks look like real ones from the time period, no longer do you just have a random table with a chair or two in the rooms like the first. So that's one good thing, otherwise the gameplay is mostly the same, just boring cuz of the mostly poor level design, enemy types, and enemy placements. Also considering how the engine works, they are certain parts that will make you really pissed, without spoiling, it's a part later on that requires "some masks". Another positive, the music and sound quality is still great. At certain points you do get great brilliance with how this is used but is often ruined by everything else i mentioned. The dialogue for voice acting is also still great and funny. 

Now i already mentioned the robotic minions of the great enemy...or not so great enemy. The new big bad guy, has no real precense in the game and once again will remind you of system shock. Think  Atlas from Bioshock but even worse. This guy has a terrible voice that just makes him annoying to listen to, he isn't intimidating at all unlike the spooky pagan god from the the first game. And there is just not real rising action, or climatic event like the first game. The last mission is easily the worst in the game and series. I'll just tell you, that you spend the last mission to "defeat" the bad guy by crafting..... CRAFTING. No portals, no real race to the clock, not spooky atmosphere. Just mundane running around crafting. 

It's so sad but it's obvious it was either made by different people or they did forget the brilliance of the first game. It's sad too cuz still has traces of first, has pretty and somewhat interesting levels, has mostly the same ideas and feel but gets ruined by their changes and lack of imagination. It's the sophmore slump, the lets return to what game was great and praised and try to do everything bigger and better rather than fix things. In the end i wish steam (once again) had the maybe option but im gonna give this one a NOT recommended. If you loved the first and wanted the 2nd, get it cheap and realize it's gonna be different and will only have a few moments of great feeling like the first while the rest of the time you slog through, just keep that in mind. There are great fan missions for it, 100s of them, so that might be the only real good reason to get this one. People often say deadly shadows went the wrong way, but this game was the start of that. So keep all this in mind. Thank you for reading my review and here's hoping for more fan missions.

This is going to be a long one so sit down and relax! As my name entitles, this is probably THE best stealth game ever made! I will go in depth why it is and why YOU should be playing it:

  Let's start off with a list. What makes a stealth game one of the greats? In my own personal opinion it is: Have engaging and functional stealth mechanics. Provide the player with alternate routes and methods of completing an objective. have interesting, unique levels. Have said levels progressively provide challenges to overcome. NO FORCED combat! And most of all, have an engaging story and setting that makes the player WANT to progress. Every stealth game I have ever played usually doesn't have all of these things checked marked on the list. MGS has forced combat and has a questionable story that tries to be over the top yet subtle at the same time. The first two Splinter Cell games were far too linear and also forced combat at times. Not to mention the sub par stories. Conviction tries way too hard to uncheck every thing on this list. Dishonored's story is cliche and is WAY to easy any way you play it (Yes, even the non lethal no powers run is too easy). Death to Spies has barely any atmosphere or story. The list goes on. That's why everyone's favorite stealth games usually are Splinter Cell Chaos Theory, the Hitman series, and other games that manage to check the checklist. What about Thief 2?

 This game checks every single thing on the list and for some parts, even goes BEYOND the criteria. Every level is HIGHLY unique, replayable, massive, and intrigueing all at the same time. From a shipping warehouse to a bank to a police station and more, no two missions are ever the same(except two that uses the same map). Not only are the locations unique, the objectives are as well. You are sneaking into the warehouse to get enough money for your RENT. You are sneaking into a bank to get evidence on the sheriff. You are going into a police station to frame a guy by placing evidence in the VAULT. Almost every level is VASTLY open and there are not two, or three, but usually FIVE ways to get into the building and there are always two ways into every room. Is there a guard in your way to the staircase to get upstairs? Go take the other two stairs and your good. Although not all missions are quite heavy hitters.( Tracing the Courier in paticular) Not to mention, Only TWO out of FIFTEEN missions in this game require you to knockout people. That means you have THIRTEEN ghostable missions. This makes this game one of the stealthiest stealth game I have ever played ( Say that 5 times fast). This game is so stealthly, the community has made terms like "supreme ghost", where you have to put back items you USED. Compare this to MGS, where they force you into combat every so often.

 Now, I wouldn't give this game the huge praise it deserves if the world and story were crap. NOPE! it is one of THE BEST settings to play in. An industrial, steam punk, fantasy world. An interesting story about how the industry is taking over the town. And interesting characters. The protaganist, Garret, is a smart mouth, no shits given guy that you WANT to play as. He has a personality that makes you want to check every nook and cranny just to see what he has to say. The factions in this game are also unique and interesting and you can probably remember their names instantly. They have their own weapons, armor, and even the way they talk. The Mechanists worship metal and technology and so they use enhanced armor and talk like a Shakespear character.(" Who art thou?") The main villian has a good purpose and is highly threatening in his own way.  The City guards are bumbling idiots who talk slow and usually get agitated easily. It just goes on and on.

 Speaking of the Mechanists, their inclusion in the game provide a great big help to the checklist. Their technology creates challenges to overcome. First you'll start off by seeing their version of "security cameras". Later, you'll see little robots of sorts that set off the alarm when spotted. There is some more, but if you have played the game you know what I mean. The levels get more massive and require more from you each time. Each gadget has it's purpose and yet is almost completely optional to help you in most levels. Using the light and shadow stealth is robust. But more importantly, the SOUND is what shines here. Different floor types have different noise levels. You can sprint on carpet, but once you get on a metal grate, expect trouble. It truly is a inspiring sound system not only to stealth games, but to game design in general. 

 The ONLY problem I have with this is not even with the game itself. It's getting this thing to work on modern PC's. If you do decide to get this game, be prepared. Get the Taffer Patch and Tf2Tool patch or else this game will probably not work for you. There are also some HD packs to help make the game more beautiful. Do I even need to say it? GET THIS GAME!!!

While I enjoyed it a lot as a stealthy game with an interesting setting, I was bothered by how so many people said that it wasn’t a true Thief game.  Unconvinced, I was told to play the originals and see for myself how different they are.  So when I saw that the series was on sale, I bought it and have been playing Thief 2 for quite some time now.  And my initial thoughts after finishing the game, is wow.  Wow, this IS an amazing game and it puts the new game to shame.   With that said, lets get into the review.

[h1]Plot[/h1]

You play as a thief named Garret.  Your goal is to perform various tasks that typically involve stealing valuables or performing sabotage.   While not all jobs require you to steal, it is a profitable activity to do.   As the story progresses, you are told about a man named Karras who is using machine-men (Robots) to do all sorts of things.  He is a worshiper of some unusual faith and thinks that making these robots will help him win favor and help the world.   Simple plot, but it's enough to make each job related and important.

[h1]Sounds[/h1]

No music, only sound effects and ambience.  For a stealth game, this is perfect because you need to focus on sounds, not music.  The sound effects used are pretty simple and hardly have any variation but it IS an old game so it was good for its time.  The voicing is pretty cliché and not that good but once again, its dated.  I believe that this was the first Thief game that had female guards whom had unique voice lines.   Footstep sounds are distinct enough to know if you are loud or not, and it varies based off what you are walking on.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

Let's be honest, its dated, period.  For back then, it wasn’t that bad, and even when using a mod that enhances the various textures, it still isnt the best.   However, the mod does make a lot of the textures look better.  On a [i]light[/i]er note, the lighting is very important in knowing if you are visible or not.  Some spots had issues where you appear to be in the light but are hidden while other times you are in the shadows but the game thinks you are visible.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

This is going to be fairly lengthy since this is the MOST important feature of Thief 2, which is why I saved this for last.   What Thief 2 gets right, are all of the mechanics for a stealth game.  The only issue right off the bat, is the enemy AI which can be exploited if you choose to.  Outside of that, the game forces you to focus on a variety of factors when playing.  Sound levels are important in knowing how loud you are.  If you walk or run on tiles, you will be heard.  If you walk or run on carpet, then you won't be heard.  If you run on a wooden floor that is above guards who are in the floor below, then they will hear you and eventually run upstairs to see who is causing all those noises.  This also has an effect on the robots in the game.  There are big robots that can hear and see you, but there are small robots that won't see you unless you make noise.   This leads you into making sure to walk carefully around the tiny bots as they wont see you and thus you can evade them, no sweat.  The game even gives you tools that assist you with these noise issues, and its in the form of an Arrow that spreads moss all over the floor, making it possible to walk, run, jump without being heard.

Another aspect to the game, are lights.  Like with any stealth game, lights are important to have and to be cautious of.  There are plenty of light sources in the game.  Some can be turned off, some can be put out by a Water Arrow, and some cannot be put out.   When many of these lights are out, they are out period, but one type can be relight so you have to be careful of guards who want to light it up. 

As mentioned earlier, the enemy AI can be wonky or unfair for human AI, but the enemies themselves are interesting.  The Human enemies typically function the same.  They respond to loud noises, dead bodies, etc.  But it’s the robot enemies that are worth mentioning.  In the game, there are about 5 or 6 robot enemies.  First type is a camera that moves back and forth and will lock onto a target if they are not hidden.  Stay visible for too long and the silent/non-silent alarms will go off and you're basically screwed.   The second type are large robots that react to sound and sightings.  They are deadly if cornered but are predictable.  The third type are the 'mini me' versions of large robots.  These type are blind but react to sound a lot faster.  Once they hear something, they will open up their eyes and look for the source.  If spotted, they immediately run to the nearest large robot or guard to alert them.  The other bots are far and few in terms of use but they have their own unique abilities like one is a child robot who cannot be stopped or destroyed, and another is a spider shaped robot.

The last basic mechanic is the archery.  I won't sugar coat it, the aiming with the bow, is pretty bad.  Some arrows have trajectory while others shoot straight.  There is no crosshair to use and often times its trial-and-error inorder to figure out how to aim.  Also, some of the hit-boxes for torches can be off too if hit at the wrong angle.  In the game, there are various types of arrows and useable items.  The arrows range from basic arrows that damage, to fire that explode, to vine arrows that allow you to create a hanging vine to use to climb places.  As for the items, they mostly consist of mines you can place to set a trap, and throwables that can help you see around corners or flash bang an enemy.

And finally, I wanted to talk about the last design aspect for the game, and that is level designing.   The maps themselves are usually fairly large in size and feature a lot of ways to approach a situation.  Just like with most games, there are your path meant for non-stealth, true stealth, and opportunists stealthers.   Its amazing how well designed the levels are because it feels like there are so many routes to take and after playing each mission for so long, you start to realize how often these paths converge into each other and that’s when it all makes sense.  Speaking of this,  secret pathways are used throughout the whole game as well as secret rooms.  Some can be obvious due to massive switches and handles, while others require some more, out of the box thinking to find.   The tricky ones are the places where the switch used is very tiny and blends in well with the background or is tiny and well hidden behind flags and posters.  For a game that was this old, it's simply amazing to see how detailed and well thought out the map creators were when designing the places.


[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]

After playing this, I still enjoyed the modern Thief game but now I can agree with others who say that Thief (2014) is a good game but NOT a good Thief game.  I won't go into details about that game, but what I can say about this one, is that it definitely set the foundation for what a true stealth game should be about.  Few games can come into comparison to it and while yes it has dated graphics and an exploitable AI thing, it’s a really damn good classic game that all stealth fans should play.  If anything it will give them a better appreciation for stealth games in general.  However, my final bit of advice is to make sure to install the Mod that patches the game and enhances the textures.  The patch itself will help prevent certain levels from being incompletable while making sure to fix issues that can cause players to escape the map or get stuck

Os desenvolvedores do Thief 2 dispuseram um tal gênio que, reconheceram e compreenderam as falácias da obra antepassada para assim conserta-las em sua sequência, cuidando-se com precaução para não quebrar em tão alto grau o espírito e as essências de como tudo atua. Essa é, quem sabe, a primordial razão que ocasionou muitos de nós eleger este acima do precedente, conquanto, não estou incluído no "nós" e explicarei o porquê.

Contemplo o método que optaram para a correção dessas falhas com incômodo. Ao invés de melhorar e aperfeiçoar a fundo as particularidades que não foram recebidas com uma tal positividade no feedback dos usuários, os criadores na ousadia descartaram as tantas imperfeições sem misericórdia alguma, que por seguimento, substituíram por outros elementos. O invulgar ar gótico e sombrio agregado as temáticas surrealistas do primeiro jogo desceram nos drenos do bulevar mais próximo, originando seu substituidor a tônica Steampunk que baseia-se na execução de modelos das tecnologias modernas por meios da ciência da antiguidade. Os mortos-vivos, monstros e fantasmas foram entes que tornaram-se tão raras que seu sumiços frutificam um iluminismo ao clima da história e espaço físico, até torna estes um tanto que cômico, já que por exemplo; as maquinas que sobrepõem o usual comparecimento das criaturas do oculto são meros inimigos que possuem movimentação precária, diálogos com gravações ridículas e é claro, a representação de um robô pateta e burro. Ao confronta-los sentirás nada mais que desagrado, enquanto para as aberrações, formularizaria-se uma tensão. Os gráficos trouxeram uma leve ampliação, com uma modelagem poligonal superior, melhores texturas e o acréscimo de efeitos climáticos. Enquanto que por outro lado, dispomos o estilo estético que, uma vez que não é usado com diferentes intenções, torna-se um tanto que frequente por uma falta de abundância entre as temáticas que os mapas retratam, o anterior fez um belo balanceamento entre o supernatural e o estilo medieval dos cenários, enquanto que este foca só na harmonia mediévico em quase todas as circunstâncias. O que efetivamente é de se conservar os olhos com alguma positividade é o quanto é aprimorado o divertimento de vários com a exclusão do foco no sobrenatural, pois, o talento dos arquitetos de níveis são muito mais elevados ao trabalharem nos níveis concentrados em metrópoles, castelos e outras construções dinâmicas onde há segurança, administração e carreira ainda vivente. Se tu não experimentou o anterior e é um fan de procedimentos esquisitos, góticos e tenebrosos, considere comprar o outro já de imediato, enquanto para os fans da tecnologia a vapor, usufruem desse.

Porventura o principal mérito identificável da jogabilidade seja logo a liberdade entregue para o jogador que lhe permite cumprir os intentos na hora e ordem que bem preferires, outrossim concede-te com inúmeros caminhos possíveis para finalizar cada nível que é concebido por meio da relevância de seres capacitado de explora-lo até seus limites, "relevância" posto que existe pouquíssimos vídeo-games que merecem uma abordagem melhor em relação a liberdade que Petralha 2, em razão de sua grandeza arquitetônica de cada mapa, nas quais apresentam inúmeras regiões secundárias que poderias ignora-las em teu traço original em destino a meta, proclamo na fé que na primeira jogada de quase todos demoraria mais de uma hora para conseguir explorar uma missão inteira, já que o conteúdo que existe a possibilidade de localizar é imenso. É digno falar dos mistérios graças ao fato de que a significação de encontra-los não está nos utensílios que eles entregam-te, claro que esse recebo é importante para aumentar tua armoria, mas, na própria forma em que eles foram designados se vê um valor maior, o que descobres é curioso e divertido de reconhecer que ainda por cima está por dentro da consistência da narração. Afinal, quem não gostaria de encontrar um hangar por onde vive um maluco que alimenta seres humanos para uma aranha gigante? Darão esses, um ar intrigante para as pessoas que sentem falta das concepções perdidas ou tornado-se raras do primeiro jogo, já que enquanto há fluorescência na superfície, atrás disso haverá as trevas que foram rotineiras na vida de Garrett, que transmite aquele familiar sentimento do oculto.

A movimentação é lenta para estimular prudência, que será necessário nas diversas vezes em que precisarás encobrir-se nas sombras da escuridão, mesmo que as vezes tu seja obrigado a fuzilar o Shift para andar mais rápido, isso nunca chegou a ser uma característica tão desagradável quanto parece. A vulnerabilidade de seu personagem é com certeza o supremo encorajador de furtividade, é possível combater contra os inimigos e mata-los no processo, mas a chance é uma minúcia tão trivial que és capaz de morrer em uma ou duas perfurações das espadas, ou de seja lá que outras maneiras eles teriam na manga para elimina-lo. O que tem de usar para com efeito alcançar os teus intuitos não é apenas o teu dom como furtador, em companhia disso, há uma infinidade de ferramentas que lhe presenteiam múltiplas utilizações e vantagens dado que cada uma possuí uma utilidade diferente, terás de conserva-las até que chegue a hora em que se tornarão indispensáveis, e perceberás que sua preservação valeu a pena. Alem disso, é importante fazer o bem proveito do som, sua propagação é de extrema importância, essa é talvez a peculiaridade mais lembrada pela comunidade quando falamos a respeito desse universo. Ouvir os passos das pessoas aproximarem-se ou desaparecerem-se na distância permite que você julgue se podes ou não arriscar progredir para uma determinada área. Inclinar-se contra as portas para ouvir conversas ou a presença de sons na próxima sala permite que determine se a abertura de uma porta é uma escolha sábia ou não, coisas pequenas assim, que necessitam de tua atenção em relação ao áudio, faz com que você como jogador, viva as consequências em momentos que não fostes atencioso.

A narrativa mantem um vínculo contínuo com a jogabilidade, cada desfecho de uma missão é dado uma cutscene que por ela é exibido o impacto que a conclusão dos teus objetivos gerou, bem como a providencia de informações sobre quais e como serão as suas próximas façanhas. Conforme o contexto que está desenrolando a conjuntura, algumas características costumeiras do teu desempenho podem mudar por conta do aumento cronológico da dificuldade que encaixa-se com o progresso dos acontecimentos; ou seja, a dificuldade tem por conta o fortalecimento que ocorre nas estruturas de defesas que por conseguinte tem suas próprias justificativas e razões por terem sucedido igualmente o protagonista tem as suas ao pôr os pés lá, tudo isso está explícito graças a essa conexão aproximada no inicio do parágrafo. Se começares a desmanchar os negócios do vilão via furto, ele aumentará a segurança de suas propriedades evidentemente, e por causa disso terás a oportunidade e talvez a obrigação de utilizar diferentes métodos de invasão para certas ocasiões. O idêntico não pode ser dito das tuas tarefas como ladro, não é que cada finalidade não seja diferente da outra, são sim, a questão é que as trajetórias para alcança-las são bastante análogas já que só diferem-se o espaço e seus desafios, na grandiosa porção das vezes é só alcançar o queijo do labirinto enquanto cargas a obrigação de superar os obstáculos para a própria sobrevivência. Não é só por meio de cenas que é informado as coletâneas de erudição que por resultado forma o enredo de Thief, existem receptores secundários no próprio meio físico de cada nível que são acessíveis via registros espalhados pelo mapa que o letrado protagonista é capaz de optar por ler, essas, dispõem a regularidade de dialogarem sobre o convívio e vivência dos determinados cenários que o nível encontra-se, então se estiver em algum escritório, é possível que talvez encontre relatos sobre negócios e comércios.

Game was released ~17 years ago upon me playing this game and writing this review. It has not aged well. Graphics will not be accounted for in the final score for this game. That being said...

+ Easy 60 FPS

Story: +10
========
You are Garrett, a professional career thief out to steal things for your own benefit and livelihood. Overall story revolves around a Machinist Cult and what they have planned for the world around them. You are but a lowly thief caught in this plan (almost unintentionally), and it may just become your goal to stop them...maybe... who knows, you'll have to play the game to find out :)

As stated in the opener, this is a glorified game of collectibles. Most levels will have random loot scattered across levels and it's your job, if you're OCD inclined, to collect everything, all while avoiding the guardians of said loot.

+ Trying to find loot in and of itself is a lot of fun. It's a great feeling to find a huge stash behind a hidden door that you almost overlooked, or discovered while backtracking. The game's name holds up.

+ Stealth mechanics, for how they're designed, work great. Stay in the shadows to avoid the guards; if you enter the light and they see you, they'll attack. Simple.

+ A nice supply of items to help you "thief your way around" each and every level. The Rope/Vine Arrow was my favorite.

35841040.review:
Esse é o primeiro jogo que eu terminei de uma lista que eu fiz com jogos do Steam que estão há mais de 4 anos no meu backlog. Mas esse jogo remonta há muitos anos antes, já que foi lançado em 2000. A grande questão que eu fiz foi: "Ainda vale a pena jogar um jogo tão datado?".

Responderei nas próximas linhas. Antes é importante que eu explique. Esse jogo foi lançado no tempo do Windows 98. Rodá-lo não é simplesmente clicar em play. Eu baixei o Taffer Patcher (TMA 218 beta). Com isso, consegui rodar e terminar o jogo, sem glitches nem bugs, num Windows 10 com hardware moderno, inclusive em 1920x1080.

Vamos então ao review. Eu joguei o primeiro Thief há muito tempo. Olhando nos meus alfarrábios (sim, eu tenho anotados os meus jogos terminados nos últimos 15 anos), terminei ele em 2003. E depois desse tempo todo, eu ainda tenho boas lembranças da mecânica daquele jogo. E essa mecânica ainda se mostra sólida depois de 17 anos. E é por ela que eu ainda recomendo esse jogo. Esqueça a história. Sem mais a participação de Ken Levine, que idealizou o primeiro game, ela é apenas um adereço. A mecânica no entanto, permanece inalterada. É a mesma experiência do primeiro Thief.

Se você fizer como eu e jogar no modo Expert, vai ter aquele desafio raiz, ainda reflexo dos anos 90, onde tive 36 horas de gameplay, pra 19 horas computadas no jogo (ou seja - morri praticamente metade do que joguei). No Expert ainda você não pode matar ninguém, exceto na última fase. Isso dificulta um bocado as coisas. Falando de fases, são 15 ao todo, algumas bem longas e desafiadoras. O maior desafio, pra mim, se encontra nas fases que não tem apenas um objetivo claro do tipo "Ir até tais lugares, fazer tais coisas e sair". São as fases que exigem um mínimo x de loot, ou encontrar x itens ou x segredos. Essas são as que tomam mais tempo, pois exigem explorar todos os cantos do cenário, nocautear cada inimigo e desabilitar todas as defesas. Pode ser mais sacal do que o esperado. Dito isso, algumas dessas fases foram um bocado irritantes, mas a maioria em geral foi divertida, ainda mais que os cenários variam bastante. Muitas das missões acabam sendo envolventes pelo desafio imposto. Foi um sentimento bem parecido com o que tive ao terminar o primeiro game.

Tecnicamente o jogo, como eu disse, é de 2000, o que significa primórdios das placas 3D e tudo mais. Os personagens são pobres em polígonos. As texturas e os cenários ainda são agradáveis, visto que o jogo suporta anti-aliasing, então, em Full HD, não é a coisa mais feia que existe por aí. As cutscenes são bem tosquinhas, com resolução bem baixa (provavelmente 800x600 ou menos).

O veredito é: Tem jogos mais modernos. [i]Dishonored[/i] é um bom exemplo de jogo que, se jogado à moda stealth, lembra bastante Thief. No entanto, esse aqui vale a pena se você:
- quer um verdadeiro desafio à moda antiga;
- não se importa com gráficos datados;
- ou ainda, se você tem um PC velhinho, que não roda o estado da arte mais atual.

NOTA 7.5/10

[b]Intro[/b]
Thief II The Metal Age is easily one of the best games of all time and the pinnacle of not only stealth in video games, but level design and story telling. I may be in the minority in saying that I prefer both the original and Deadly Shadows more,
but goddamn if this isn't a worthy successor in every way, continuing the series and building upon the world that you helped shape by the end of the last game.

[b]The Great:[/b]
++The sound design in this game is phenomenal. The propogation engine, the voice acting, how it effects gameplay, everything is just at the highest standard possible which is to say totally unmatched.
++The cutscenes in this game are, again, and I'll be repeating this a few times, totally unmatched within video games as a whole
++The atmosphere is extraordinary, even if it isn't as strong as Dark Project or Deadly Shadows
++Levels can take an hour or more to complete and are totally rewarding the whole way through
++The sneaking is just plain fun

[b]The Good:[/b]
+Graphics are a noticable improvement over the Dark Project more so in consistency and art style then technical acheivement.
+Using Tafferpatcher, I couldn't ask for smoother performance on modern systems
+Levels are huge, but not for the sake of being huge

[b]The Okay/Not Too Big of a Deal:[/b]
+-The soundtrack by Eric Brosius was made to be more musical than ambiant and it doesn't work nearly as well. It's in no way bad though.

+-What the hell are the point in vine arrows? I used them like once for metal surfaces the whole game.

[b]The Bad:[/b]

-Movement seems to glitch on surfaces more than the first game which is quite frustrating

-The storyline is only half as good as Thief the Dark Project or Deadly Shadows

The two before it are the worst in the game besides it and it really doesn't help that both levels are exactly the same in layout with terrible level design.
---I honestly find the level design to be a large step back from the original. There's a reason the entirety of Follow the Courier's concept was only a tiny section of Assassin's back in Gold. I've played Thief II multiple times and never get tired of it.  I have the game on CD but bought the Steam version because my CDs no longer play the end mission videos.  Those videos push the story along and the plot is much better with them.  The game is similar to a first person shooter but the best way to play is on the hardest difficulty level in which you aren't allowed to kill any humans--you have to play by stealth.  I have to say, knocking out a guard with a blackjack is much more satisfying even than killing a boss in many other FPS games.  At the same time, it's still a lot of fun to kill a guard from a distance with an arrow at lower difficulty levels.  I never did succeed at killing guards with a sword--I just take too much damage.

Every mission is different--reconnaissance, rob a mansion, escape an ambush, blackmail someone, follow someone undetected and more.  Weapons are varied and most are useful for things other than killing enemies--a rope arrow to climb, water arrow to put out torches, moss arrow to dampen sound on hard flooring etc.   Don't worry, you still get to kill nonhuman critters (and humans in lower difficulty levels).  While all of these elements make for excellent game play, Thief II's plot is wonderful.  One of my only critiques is that the plot should be advanced farther within the missions than through the end of mission vidos.

The look and feel is not outdated even though the game is almost 20 years old; in fact, I hope there's a 20th anniversary edition--I'd buy that in a heartbeat!

9.9/10

The first Thief game was an innovation, a pioneer in the field of stealth games. Its sequel surpassed it masterfully. (Some spoilers ahead.)

In 2000, at the turn of the century, Looking Glass Studios were not looking hot. Despite their massive successes with Thief: The Dark Project and, one year later, System Shock 2, the studio was nearing bankruptcy. They were only kept afloat by Eidos as part of their contract, but their sacrifices, and eventual closure almost immediately following Thief 2's launch, were worth it, as this game can be called their swan song.

The idea behind the game is simple. Instead of killing the enemies you encounter, you're mostly supposed to sneak by them instead, pilfer whatever they're guarding, and make your getaway. The gameplay is almost exactly the same as Thief 1, with some changes I will write about in a few paragraphs.

At the end of the first game, Garrett is warned about the dawn of the Metal Age by the Keepers. As the second game starts, The City is seen in a full industrial revolution, spearheaded by a breakaway faction of the Hammerites, known as the Mechanists. Their leader, Karras, is a gifted inventor, and directs his Friends, as they call each other, to work on new technology to benefit all. At the same time, greenery in The City begins to fade as part of this wave of changes. Garrett will re-enter this world as usual, doing contracts for his 'pals' or just for himself, but becomes pursued by an emergent police force, possessors of Mechanist technology and a zero tolerance policy on crime.

One thing I should mention about Garrett is that he definitely comes across as more fleshed-out. His personality is mostly the same gruff, darkly-humoured realist-cynic, but he takes plenty of opportunities to display it, in the game itself and in cinematics. Speaking of cinematics, they, and really the entire game, are a lot more polished than its predecessor's. Together with a change in theme from darkness and abandoned places to more homely, cozy areas made colder by the sound of metal grinding on metal comes a facelift in texture work and art style, marking Thief 2 as a clear sequel.

This change of technology has brought about a few new toys to play with and plenty of obstacles that stand in Garrett's path to riches. Flares exist as items that can be activated, carried and thrown to help with pitch black areas. Additionally, Garrett's eye can now interface with another new item called a Scouting Orb, which can be thrown like any other item, allowing the player to see through it. Scouting Orbs can even be picked up and re-used!

However, with new toys come new enemies they must be used against, all of them mechanical in nature, ranging from rudimentary cameras called Watchers to patrolling automatons armed with cannons, impervious to simple swords and arrows, and requiring Garrett to think of some other way to eliminate them or sneak by them.

On the graphical front, the game uses the same Dark engine used for Thief 1 and System Shock 2 before it, albeit made to look pretty for the times. Otherwise, it's exactly the same as Thief 1 on all fronts. What Thief 2 has instead of innovation is a gripping story, with some unexpected twists and turns, more human locales to be visited, conversations to be overheard, and mysteries to be discovered. Even the enemy AI has improved visibly from the first game.

To sum up, if you liked Thief 1, you'll love Thief 2. The developers' experience shows, as the game has been improved on all fronts. And if you finish the game and want more, check out Thief 2X, a fan-made expansion released in 2005, or any number of other fan-made maps.

28776100.review:
This shadow-based stealth game builds on everything its predecessor began.

To start, I'd like to say that this game is the masterpiece of its series and is a must-buy if you are even somewhat interested in the stealth genre.
Almost everything about this game is perfect.

You play as thief, god-killer, absolute legend Garrett and try to get to the bottom of the schemes of Karras, a shady figure who really likes steampunk and selling robots and cameras to fucking everyone.  As a sneaky boy who likes to hit fleshy people with blackjacks, these robots and cameras will present a large problem to you.  Funnily enough, if you beat the absolute shit out of a robot with your blackjack for long enough, it will break, but it is easier to incapacitate them first with one of your water arrows (which are in limited supply) to their engines.

Level design is fantastic, better than the first game's.  Each level is nonlinear and massive in size.  The enemy AI is good, and does not fall apart when they start to look for Garrett (unlike this game's predecessor in which they simply moved toward Garrett while they looked for him).  Just like the last game, you have an arsenal of gadgets at your disposal that allow for unparalleled creativity in how you can approach an objective, including the iconic rope arrow (which allows for tons of creativity just on its own).  Enemies are diverse and challenging, and the levels often require you to find hidden areas or encourage you to find secrets.
Sword combat returns almost unchanged, which is good for the most part, but the abusability of overhead swings on human targets is the only flaw I can find with this game.

One of the greatest stealth games of all time: 9.5/10

28150130.review:
In [i]Thief II[/i] we see the return of Garrett as he faces a new threat that has arisen because the equilibrium was disturbed after his previous venture. The new foe will seem unbeatable from our hero perspective, who, as usual, just wants to be on his own and make a living by what he does best, thieving, a thing that won't go far for him because a new faction that rises to power in The City will interrupt his schemes. The situation calls again for the master thief as he gradually involves himself in the unfolding of the master plan behind this new faction and its leader.

Again, like in the previous game, [i]Thief I[/i], I chose to install a mod for some minor fixes I've read that this game needs, although from my experience, at least, with these two games I have never encountered a single crash or any major inconvenience (excepting here the fact that Garrett is totally lacking basic ladder climbing skills). I chose a simple and light mod, without graphical enchantments called New Dark (Unofficial patch), which, as the name suggests, is a patch, namely a community patch. Regarding the game itself, as a whole, I can say that it is largely similar with its predecessor, with a few improvements, of course. The difference is seen when we look at the story, the first game focusing more on the old ways, nature and the world beyond while this game centers its story inside The City and its altering under the Mechanists.

Altogether this game didn't disappoint, as expected, and it is, for me at least, as good as the first game. Give it a go if you have finished [i]Thief I[/i].

28096622.review:
Thief 2 - это шедевр. Просто шедевр среди стэлс экшонов. Эта игра взяда всё самое лучшее из Thief, умножила на 3, доработала и добавила нововведений и фишек.

[h1] Плюсы [/h1]
[list]

[*] Исправления. В игре, в отличии от первой части, исправили всё.[u] Во первых [/u], вам не прийдётся больше лазить по каким-то измерениям и драться с демонами из Doom, монстрами, бессмертными тварями и т.д. и т.п. Теперь вы будете грабить (в 95% случаях) дома, причём локации с этими зданиями или целыми городами просто мастодонтски-гигантские. Вы можете часа 3 грабить этот дом, и то проспидранить тщательно ничего не иследовав. Локации время от времени поражают своими размерами. Ещё, как я уже говорил - никаких монстров. Нету этих супер-бесячих противных убожеских зомби, нету этих обрыганов с двумя конечностями, от запаха изо рта которых ты умираешь. Убрали почти всех кроме людей, которых кстати доработали. Новое снаряжение так же завезли - допустим "Scouting Orb" - сфера, как камера, которую ты можешь кинуть за угол и дистанционно посмотреть что она видит, оставаясь при этом за углом. В добавок подвезли несколько зелек и прочих плюшек, которые, впрочем, вводят в игру разнообразие.

[*] Идеи. Идеи в игре очень обширны, ы ней можно проходить уровень как тебе удобней - делать то что тебе удобней, выбирать себе тактику и так далее - такого в те времена ещё особо небыло. У персонажа есть довольно неплохой арсенал, как лук (с огромным кол-вом вилов стрел для разных нужд и работ), меч и дубинка для вырубания противников. Так же есть тут какое-то подобие инвентаря куда вы можете брать всё - начиная с вооружения что лежит на уровне, заканчивая едой и драгоценностями. Хочу подметить что игра эта во вселенной Steampunk, и сражаться вам прийдётся не только с людьми, но и с машинами.
[/list]

[h1] Минусы [/h1]

Минусов в этой игре минимальное кол-во. Из недостатков здесь только то, что слегка поломали систему паркура, теперь персоонаж хочет только на высокие выступы залезать, а то что ему по колено, видите ли, не нравится. Причём таких припятствий много - и зачастую просто перепрыгнуть их не получается, а когда всё же перепрыгиваешь - все вокруг это слышат. Так же, как минус могу отметить то, что в этой игре застрять в текстурах не мудрено, хотя не справоцировав это поломанным паркуром ты и не застрянешь, но всё равно не приятно.

Хотелось бы сказать что игра довольно атмосферная, и в стиле Steampunk, и затягивает она не хило. Зайдя в игру, можно вв ней застрять на часа 2, а потом с довольной моськой, отходя от компьютера, думать, что же ты будешь делать в следующий раз и сколько на это уйдёт времени.

Игра - пример, когда сиквелл лучше оригинала. 
Оценка игре   -=93/100=-
Оценка МОИХ ощущений  -=80/100=- 
[b] ВЕЛИКОЛЕПНО! [/b]

This game, like its predecessor Thief 1, grasped the essentials of stealth gameplay almost 15 years ago. No game since has done anything like this, which is why Thief 2: The Metal Age remains at the top of any list of games with stealth focus even today.

Aside from the fantastic stealth gameplay, it is the atmosphere created by the interplay of level, sound and lighting design that serves to fully immerse the player into Thief's steampunk setting after the initial shock of the dated graphics has worn off. The textures might look blurry, the particle effects on streetlights like something out of an 80's arcade game, and the polygon count in single digits, but none of it matters once you have sneaked past the first guard, relieving him of his purse in the process.

The horror elements of the first Thief are a bit more subdued in the sequel, and more emphasis is placed on the pure stealth and thievery aspects, which is something I personally prefer. However, the story is just as gripping as in Thief 1, with old aquaintances making an appearance and old feuds buried for the sake of new make-shift alliances. I would definitely recommend you play Thief 1 first, and then return to play Thief 2, if only to be able to fully appreciate the story of Thief 2.

I must have played through this game at least 10 times if not more over the years, and even though I could probably find my way through most of the levels without looking at the screen, it has not lost any of its appeal.

27168995.review:
[h1]«Thief II: The Metal Age» – стелс-экшен, обогнавший своё время на несколько десятков лет.[/h1]

Жанр «стелс-экшен» был рожден задолго до Кодзимы с его серией “Metal Gear”, но именно он смог развить идеи, которые до него никто не был способен реализовать по той причине, что большинство покупателей не были готовы к замене бравых и мужественных парней, способных одним кулаком разломить вражескую базу, а другим кулаком прижать лицо суперзлодея к стенке, на обычного хилого солдата , который мог упасть на пол после двух пуль , всаженных ему в тело. Нынешний покупатель также готов отказаться от весьма замудренного «стелса» в пользу однотипного конвейерного боевичка , что лишний раз подтверждает статистика продаж. На сегодняшний день элементы «стелса» есть практически в любой игре, начиная с коридорных шутеров, заканчивая огромными RPG с эпическим размахом. Так или иначе, данный жанр старается не столько эволюционировать, сколько внедриться в другие в качестве приятного бонуса или же отдельного пути для прохождения как одного задания, так и игры в целом, а потому встретить игры, нацеленные лишь на тематику «бесшумного подкрадывания» на сегодняшний день практически невозможно. 

Но вернемся, опять же, к ХХ веку. В 1998 году отгремел “Metal Gear Solid", полный отсылок к шпионским боевикам того времени, имеющий великолепный сюжет , потрясающие диалоги и интересный геймплей. Спустя каких-то два с лишним месяца выходит игра «Thief: The Dark Project , мгновенно ставшая хитом и получившая признание как прессы, так и игроков, а после через два года выходит сиквел «Thief II: The Metal Age».Но что помогло данной серии игр получить культовый статус? В этом нам и предстоит разобраться. Перед началом хочется отметить, что сравнивать данную игру с “MGS” все равно что сравнить помидоры с огурцами, то есть спорить можно долго , но ни одна из сторон не придет к какому-либо выводу, ведь обе игры разной направленности и нацелены на абсолютно разную аудиторию.

Основной отличительной чертой данной серии стала камера, которая располагалась от первого лица, что позволило по-настоящему вникнуть в роль вора. Идея, конечно, не нова, ибо в вышедшем за год до «Вора» «Golden Eye 007» также имелся вид от первого лица , но сама игра хоть и имела элементы стелса , но была все же шутером. Также стоит отметить техническую составляющую, а именно движок , благодаря которому разработчики смогли реализовать отличные тени и свет. Одной из лучших сторон игры всегда была атмосфера, которая содержала в себе мрачный стимпанк с элементами фентези в эпохе средневековья. Главный герой, как понятно из названия , вор , который себя не жалеет ради получения лишнего гроша в свой карман , а имя его – Гаррет. Несмотря на молчаливость во время миссий, в катсценах раскрываются черты его характера , а именно: алчность , циничность и жадность до денег. Сюжет рассматривать не вижу смысла , т.к. ничего сверхъестественного в нем нет, но вот о геймплее стоит все же упомянуть , ибо он опережал по проработке многие игры того времени. Игровой процесс был весьма разнообразен , ведь предлагал различное количество путей для решения одной поставленной задачи. Каждое задание начиналось с закупа нужных вам вещей, таких как стрелы , бомбы и т.д. В инвентаре у ГГ всегда имеется меч , дубинка , набор отмычек и лук. Последние три являются основными и использовать приходится их на каждом шагу. Если с дубинкой и отмычками все ясно, то лук предлагал разные виды стрел: огненные, водяные и обычные. Водяные могли устранять факелы, благодаря чему вы спокойно можете проходить в тенях мимо охраны , а огненные и обычные стрелы нужны были для истребления этой самой охраны. В остальном это обычный стелс-экшен, но разбавленный огромным  кол-ом. Основным отличием от первой части является уклон в сторону стимпанка. В остальном игра остается одной из самых хардкорных  и культовых представителей жанра «стелс-экшен».

Напоследок хочется отметить, что возраст игры не позволяет запустить ее без лишних костылей на новых операционных системах и широкоформатных мониторах, а потому для комфортной игры вам придется поставить парочку фанатских патчей.

Итог: игра обогнала время не своей графикой, не атмосферой, а отлично поданным и проработанным геймплеем с превосходными уровнями и массой контента. Все это создало отличный стелс-экшен, который не забывают и по сей день.

In 2016, it’s hard to say something about Thief II that hasn’t already been said. While Looking Glass Studios may have invented the modern stealth genre with Thief: The Dark Project, they perfected it with The Metal Age. This game’s innovative use of sound, sprawling level design, and impressive amount of player agency, create an experience that still immerses me to this day.
 
Metal Age’s missions consist of sprawling sandboxes that allow the player to pursue objectives in whatever way they see fit. Along with the wide variety of tools spread throughout these missions (arrows, mines, bombs, etc.), there are practically infinite ways to traverse any given level. The levels themselves are set in a wide range of pseudo-medieval locations. As master thief Garrett, you’ll be robbing banks, breaking into manors, trailing people through city streets, and so much more. What's really incredible about The Metal Age is that in all of its vastness and player choice, it always manages to feel organic. During my time with Thief II, I never felt like a guy in his computer chair, I really felt like a master thief. This feeling of total immersion is greatly aided by Looking Glass‘ creative and dynamic use of sound. Your footsteps make different noises at different volumes depending on what surface you walk on. You can lean against doors to hear a muffled conversation between two guards. Every coin, key, chest, door, and ladder, makes appropriate jingles, creaks, and thumps. Eric Brosius’ composition work deserves special mention here. While not traditionally musical, Thief II‘s soundtrack expertly creates a nocturnal and ominous ambiance that never really comes to the forefront, but is always present.

While it should be clear by this point that I consider Thief II to be a classic, I don’t believe it’s a perfect game. The Metal Age‘s most glaring flaw is in its visual fidelity. As a 3D game that's over a decade-and-a-half old, the graphics have aged somewhat unfavorably. Models are low-poly, with rigid animations and less than great texture work. While the dated graphics didn’t break my own personal immersion while playing, if you’re the kind of player who finds low-poly graphics to be distractingly jarring, this game may not pull you in as much as it has others. While not as much of a sticking point as the visuals, Thief II has one more notable flaw. The two missions prior to the final mission are practically identical, down to reusing the same map and having dangerously similar objectives. Neither mission is particularly bad, but the needless redundancy so close to the game’s conclusion may be frustrating for some players.

That being said, these two flaws are relatively minor tarnishes on what I consider to be a nearly perfect game in terms of player choice, level design, and use of audio. Some classic games are recognized for their influence on the medium of games as a whole, whether it be a innovative mechanic, or even inventing an entire genre. However, we often return to these games and find them to be dated or unentertaining. Thief II: The Metal Age serves as a welcome exception to this trend, and has stood the test of time to become one of the greatest stealth games ever made.            


Overall Score: 9/10

+ Huge Levels
+ Multiple Paths / Choices Through Missions
+ Great Setting Variety
+ Good use of Sound
+ Highly Immersive

- Dated Graphics
- One Redundant Mission

This is quite possibly the best stealth experience I have ever had. Thief 2: The Metal Age improves upon Thief: The Dark Project (or in our case, Thief: Gold) in every way imaginable. With a greater focus on grand medieval heists and a more focused story along with more polished gameplay this game is by far the best entry in the series.

Thief 2 begins some time after the events of Thief: TDP. What makes Thief great in terms of story telling is how fluid and well-paced it is. Starting the game by helping out a friend, then stealing enough loot just to pay your rent until eventually Garrett stumbles on a great threat and then an even greater threat pulling the strings from higher up.

Each mission can take you an hour or more to complete. The level design is superb: many rooms boast different types of surfaces which make varying amounts of noise with carpet and grass being the most quiet and tile and metal being the loudest. This game takes advantage of verticality with rope arrows and eventually vine arrows. You can really feel like a Thief when you set up a rope arrows on the roof of a building and lower yourself down to steal a highly valued item and them shimmy back up just before a guard shows up. Levels range from a bank, to a police station to a huge 6 story mansion to an underground base that houses a submarine. There's a lot of variety to be had when it comes to level setting in this game which is greatly appreciated.

Gameplay has largely stayed the same but with the addition of a few new gadgets and enemy types. After the events of Thief: TDP Garrett now has a mechanical eye he can make use of, he can use scanning orbs to make sure places are safe before continuing which is a welcome addition. The game also boasts many new enemies such a robots, security cameras and even more varied guard types. For example there are guards wearing thick helmets who cannot be knocked out with the black jack. The best you can do is stun them and when you hit them their helmet will make a loud noise and draw the attention of other guards, luckily these helmet-toting guards are easy to identify. If you disturb guards enough they will be on 24/7 alert. If guards see a pool of blood from you murdering someone they will search the area thoroughly and continue to do so until you are either caught or if you knock them out or kill them. The AI can vary to being absolutely brain-dead (hiding in the shadows and one gets close enough to smell Garrett's breath but doesn't notice him) to being way too sensitive (one step into a dimly lit room and they're already chasing you).Luckily this doesn't happen too often for it to be a serious problem but it does happen.

Lastly the sound design is superb. You can hear foot steps of enemies just as well as they can hear yours, you can hear them whistling and talking in a realistic manner. The ambient sounds bring atmosphere to the missions. Whether it be the whistling of the wind, the moans of undead, music at a party or people writing while doing paper work. Thief 2 has amazing sound direction.

This game is old and the graphics are dated with a few problems here and there. But the gameplay and atmosphere outshine all of that. I have never had a stealth experience that comes anywhere close to this game or its predecessor. The game does benefit from having a fan-made patch (brings modern widescreen resolutions to the setting, allows modding and playing of fan missions and fixes a few bugs) which can be found if you go to the guides section of the community page. 25068495.review:
Thief II: The Metal Age is a 2000 stealth game, developed by the now-defunct Looking Glass Studios, the successor of the widely acclaimed yet underrated Thief The Dark Project (1998), considered by many as the pioneer of modern stealth game, released along other amazing stealth titles such as Tenchu and Metal Gear Solid.  Being the least known of those 3 (at least from my point of view), Thief, for me,  is the most advanced on how a sneaking game should be, and that’s coming from someone who don’t have nostalgia glasses attached at all.

[h1]Dawn of The Metal Age [/h1]

You take the role of Garrett, the cynical, sarcastic, and somewhat selfish master thief, with his only goal is to steal enough goods to pay his rent. A pretty interesting hero (or antihero) in the get go isn’t he? That very attitude, skill, and notoriety is the source of the problem on both games. You start off by having a couple of disconnected missions, before the real problem takes off. Thief Gold (I’ll just call the first one Thief Gold from now on)  has a pacing issues in the first couple of missions, because they’re kind of a long ”introductory” missions. Setting up the Thief universe, Garrett as a character, and it’s gameplay mechanics, and then it becomes a bizarre and intense supernatural horror story. 

With all the universe building stuffs is done by the first one, and all the supernatural mumbo-jumbo gone (not completely, but it put in bare minimum). Thief II doesn’t have to suffer with all of these, it has a better pacing, more focused, more intricate dystopian-thriller story, set in an even more well realized steampunk setting. From a “modest” manor to a high security, 6 story towers, from stealing lowly goods to ancient mask, Thief has a unique storytelling, we all are as clueless as Garrett is,  all the story elements dropped in the perfect time and place. Take example for Karass, the antagonist, the common people only know him as “The guy who leads The Mechanists Order”, and so does Garrett, and us, the player view him, and he becomes a more threatening figure, and that’s through texts and overall environmental storytelling only. 

[h1]Stealth At It’s Purest Form [/h1]

While Thief Gold is a thieving game turned-supernatural stealth-semi-platformer halfway, The Metal Age is a “thieving simulator” all the way to  the end. Thief II is simply a much more refined version of Thief I, minus the annoying zombies, and maze-like location, my biggest gripe with Thief I. Improved graphic, making a more beautiful contrast between light and dark, and improved sound design. All thanks to  the amazing “Dark Engine”, an engine designed for Thief, and Thief alone, and yes, I know System Shock 2 use this engine too, but Dark Engine truly shows it’s technical prowess here. It has a unique aesthetic and probably the best “built-in” directional sound design ever. Even until now, I can’t think of any game that has a directional sound so spot on even without the help of a software and hardware  

Thief is a stealth game at  it’s purest, most immersive form. Your ear, eyes, patience, and common sense is your greatest strength. Thief is a slow, I mean, really slow stealth game, especially on expert where you can’t kill any humans. Stay in the shadow, lean on every corner, creep your way around, and be patient and spatially aware, because once you’re caught, well, you're one dead thief, especially if you play on expert

The interface is minimalistic, there’s your health, your light gem, and inventory. No mini map and quest markers.  That help a lot with the immersion, you are lead to appreciate and respect the surrounding area, the unique art style and layout in each level, heightened your spatial awareness.

There's one flaw in this game and that's the AI, they are... inconsistent. Ranging from nearly blind/deaf (or both), to superhuman sense. You might think the AI gets smarter every time you advance to the next level, well.. to an extent yes, but for the most part, it's "unpredictable".

[h1] The Art of Level Verticality [/h1]

Two defining characteristic of Thief, that Thief II managed to improved, as I said earlier are the sound design and level design. I won’t delve deeper into sound design, because there’s not much to write about. It’s simply amazing, spot on, and overall has a defining "exaggerated" sound design. Let’s focus on level design for now. It’s FANTASTIC, it’s huge, titanic huge, believable, follows architectural logic, and has an "oppressive" atmosphere throughout that fit with the theme very well. Unlike the second half of Thief Gold, when the level goes total mindfuck, in a good way, mostly. In term of level scenery, Thief Gold has more variation, from tomb, prison, cathedral, ruins, and mansions. Thief II levels are all worldly architecture. Only one level that goes to Thief Gold territory and that happens to be my least favorite level. As I said, it’s huge, more complex, but logical complex, that what makes Thief II a more fun experience than Gold. It’s harder to get lost, even if I do it’s easy to get back on track, making the exploration much more enjoyable. 

The level verticality is simply astounding, so many paths, some is more obvious than others, some require keen eyes and careful exploration, some requires you to hear conversations and reading notes. It’s so rewarding every time you enter a room, and realize there are 3 or more ways to get in / across. There is a vent that connects that room to the basement, the celling that connects to the attic, there’s always the so obvious ground hallway, or you can move through the interconnected rooms and picking up loots and notes, and oh! There’s a secret passage if you put out that fire, saves my time from creeping out this place!  Every route is fun to take on, making every level looks larger than it is. Besides there’s no better feeling when stumble across some loots on the way. 

[h1] Less Is More [/h1]

One major flaw in the gaming industry trend nowadays is the fact that a lot of today’s games forget the phrase “Less is more”, the removal of an element hold the same importance, or even greater importance nowadays, as adding one. They take a shotgun approach, throwing everything that looks cool hoping it will sticks. It’s not necessarily bad, but with that design philosophy in mind, a game will become a “Jack of all trades, master of none” and directionless. That’s a plague that need to put in moderation.

Thief in the other hand, is already set out to be a hardcore stealth game from the very start. It’s simple and humble in presentation, and that’s what makes it works in perfect harmony.  With a “realistic stealth/thieving game” in mind, Looking Glass can focus on what’s important on  a stealth game. The combat is terrible, the gadgets are mostly stealth oriented, you are “forced” to do the stealthy way, but it’s fine, it’s a stealth game after all. It’s not about playstyles in Thief, it’s about the route you take and they deliver.

[h1] Through The Looking Glass [/h1]

If I have to pick what’s the most underrated game developer for me, it’ll be a tie between Looking Glass and Black Isle. Though I might choose Looking Glass, because Thief, System Shock, and Ultima Underworld are less known than Black Isle’s Fallout series alone. Without them, there’ll be no Ion Storm (Deus Ex), Irrational (BioShock), and Arkane (Dishonored), it’s no coincidence that all of them are such  a hit. So short lived yet so influential, A timeless stealth game Thief II Is. A more than worthy successor of an already near-flawless game, and a perfect game to end an era.

This game definitely deserve the "Test of Time" award
