Thief 2, The Metal Age was a game that I very much enjoyed playing, and although it’s quite old, I still think it holds up very well. 
In Thief 2, you play as Garrett, a master thief who must overcome recent trouble involving a corrupt Sheriff who has cracked down on crime, and who seems to have a personal grudge against Garrett. Throughout the game, you must sneak around in various missions and locations, all while uncovering a potentially much larger problem that goes beyond Garrett himself.
 In terms of gameplay, it plays similar to the first Thief game. You sneak around, completing various objectives, all while trying to remain unnoticed. While combat is an option, Garrett is rather unequipped when it comes to fighting enemies, and stands little chance against more than one foe at a time. Stealth is by far the best option, and Thief 2 still holds up as one of the best stealth games i’ve played. Guards have long, unpredictable patrols they take, meaning they don’t simply walk from one end of the room to the other making them easy targets, which keeps the game tense and forces the player to always be on their toes in case a guard shows up unexpectedly. Guards are always alert, and will investigate a noise they hear. If they catch a glimpse of you, they may decide to look around, forcing the player to keep moving so that they aren’t found. Garrett’s main means of hiding is darkness. By hiding in the shadows, guards won’t be able to spot the player, allowing them to sneak around unnoticed. The mechanic of hiding in darkness and being exposed in the light works excellently in the game, and it was quite revolutionary for its time. Another interesting mechanic is how not all floors produce the same amount of noise when stepped on. Things like carpet and grass will produce little noise, while marble floors will produce more noise, potentially bringing guards over as well. As you progress through the game and begin stealing from richer people, more marble flooring will be found and more electric lights will be used, meaning it will get harder to keep quiet and stay in the dark.
 The level design is some of the best i’ve seen, even an improvement on the excellent design of the first game. Levels are non-linear, large, and open, and can have many different sections, each with their own ways to sneak around undetected. The levels are also very varied. Some you may find yourself in a huge mansion, some in the streets of the city, and in many other locations as well. Garrett will have a large array of tools at his disposal to help him through the levels, including many different types of arrows such as water and vine arrows that will help in certain scenarios. 
Thief 2 also wisely gets rid of the more paranormal settings and enemies that were common in the first game and replaces them with more stealth focused ones. In the first Thief, many of the levels revolved around ruins and caves filled with enemies such as zombies. These levels didn’t offer much in terms of stealth, and for the most part involved simply running right by the enemies while avoiding their attacks. Enemies such as zombies are rarely seen in Thief 2, and luckily don’t break the flow of the stealth gameplay. Thief 2 does use new enemies in the form of robots, but luckily they can be snuck around, making them similar to guards. They also offer a good challenge, because they cannot be knocked out, and throughout playing the game I never once destroyed one. I don’t even know if it was possible to destroy one in the game at all.
The game and the people in it also have a lot of charm. Garrett isn’t some lifeless protagonist; he’s a man who can take a moment seriously, but isn’t afraid to make a few cynical remarks about the people he’s stealing from. He isn’t some special hero who people shower with praise, he’s just a guy trying to make enough money from stealing to pay his rent. The guards in the game also have excellent, sometimes quite funny dialogue, and the drunken tone of their voice is a great way to get across their character. 
The story itself is also very good, and is often told in a non-direct fashion, meaning the player will learn more about the story and world by reading notes left on people's desks, listening to guards talking to each other, as well as other ways. This also gives players more of a reason to look around and explore the environments. While the story itself may seem simple at first, it slowly builds up and becomes something more. It’s rarely a flashy story, but it’s subtle, as well as intriguing and interesting at the same time.

The Metal Age is stealth game perfection. Even though a lot of the stealth mechanics don't make much sense, such as a guard not being able to see you should you be standing inches away from them if you're in a dark spot of a brightly lit room, everything about this game is FUN. You'll spend about 40-60 minutes in each level, and that's if you're ignoring picking up all of the loot that's scattered around.

The story, in comparison to the original Thief, is very well written and intriguing. The plot in the original had you fighting zombies and tomb raiding, while in this game, the focus is on the transition from a dark ages fantasy game to "The Metal Age". You don't feel so much like a spelunking knight with a sword and bow and arrow, but an actual thief, taking on bank heists and even sneaking through a medieval police station and stealing from the evidence vault. 

The screenshots displayed on the Store Page really don't do the game justice. For a game from 2000 the graphics have aged tremendously, and the lighting and texture work look fantastic to this day. My favorite level is the bank, just because of how spectacular the green tiled floors, wooden walkways, and red carpeted offices look. 

Not only do the levels look incredible, but they have some pretty great layouts and the level design is ingenious, inventive and sprawling. After replaying the bank mission so many times I've found six different ways to enter the building, and there are so many different routes you can take to get to the vault without being spotted it's insane. From crawling through a vent and dropping down into the offices adjacent to the vault room, shutting down the mechanical faces (which act as cameras hanging from the ceiling and spinning around trying to spot you) by flipping a switch on the third floor and going through the teller gates, or going through the lions den and using a rope arrow attached to the ceiling to cross the Guard's Room and into the backdoor of the vault room. 

I also love that each section of the immensely huge levels has a little nugget of dialogue to be heard that are entertaining to listen to and informative. The voice acting isn't great, but I always ended up quicksaving each time I heard a guard speaking with another guard so I could hear the full thing and then quickload so I didn't lose any time. What is really well done however is Garret talking to himself, usually stating the obvious but it helps players stay on track when he explains something to himself the player might not already realize. His little quips and things he says never get old, even after you've played the same level three or four times.

In conclusion, this is an outstanding gem of a game that you would be doing yourself a disservice not to play.

Thief 2: The Metal Age is a direct sequel to the Thief: The Dark Project, this one released in 2000 and made by Looking Glass. At the core it uses same mechanics and even same techonology of engine as the original, so some might think of it as expansion pack. Yet it's upper level of design is different, being designed like a proper stealth game and having more steampunk setting.

Also, yea, you probably heard that this version doesn't have credits music. It's not a false statement, but it's not suppose to have one to begin with. It's just that localizator of German version decided to add some song from some German band. Doesn't sound Thief-like at all.

Technically, it's released as-is and thus has some problems. Like, it doesn't support widescreen resolution or anything more than 800x600.
I think that just like with Thief 1 on Steam, to see cutscenes you have to run .exe file with admin rights. But I think it already does it?
I also noticed that the gamma slider doesn't work either. And in this one I felt that the game is way too dark by default. Or maybe Thief 1 is the one which is too bright. Not sure.
Also, yea, enable fogging in options, it's art-improving graphic option, not "hide things if far away".

Then again, you probably should use one of a community patches. Not sure how much do they change, I was there for Vanilla experience, but people love those, so.

Plot once again follows our cynical thief by the name of Garrett in the mysterious City. In the first game he had to destroy the Trickster, god of Pagans house of nature, who wished to destroy everything man-build. This heroic deed shifted the balance of powers toward the path of progress, to a dawn of the twisted Metal Age. Pure fantasy elements and monsters are almost not seen, The City is being cleaned by the City Watch and a new Mechanists sect emerges out of Hammerite house to lead the age.

And yea, the story continues, as everything here shifts to steampunk and Victorian setting. And Thief is focusing more on just being a thief, rather than adventurer. No more adventure, you now have big houses and mansion to rob and even your maps are always accurate and provide good description to let you. It even feels less linear due to this, albeit actual levels are less dragged due to less maze-like qualities and less of fetching and puzzles. But hey, this is what people expect Thief to be.

And it futher embraces the fact that it's more focused on stealth. You got new tools of trade, like Invinsibility potions, slow-fall one. There is a scouting orb that you can throw anytime and see from it's point of view, which I always forget to use even though AI never notices this so there is no good reason not to. Remember kids - don't be like me, that's not smart choice.
You can now lean into door to eaversdrop. Guards pretty much always mumble something to themselves, futher giving you audio hints. Some rare guards even wear special helmets that you can't blackjack them. Althrough they are so rare that I don't remember any such encounter. There are even occasional patrol that have more than one person.

And it's a Metal Age that we are talking about, with Mechanists bringing new toys to watch out. There are surveliance camera, security systems and robots, which can be divided into huge dangerous robot that can't hear and small robot that can only warn others, but only after first hearing you, activating their vision and seeing you. All mixed with humans, giving more stealth-focused variety instead of monsters. All while you are cracking the bank level with it's ceramic tiles and three floors of complexity.

Albeit, it does mean that it lost some of the charm. There isn't much of wonderful immersive mystery that made me fall in love for Thief. That, and I am not fan of this theme, it's just feels too Victorian. It mostly has to do that it actually lost some gameplay variety. There is only so much mansion that you can crack at before it gets a bit old. Which isn't to say that there is no rare mission which goes out of this style. And it also varies the stealth objective that you have, even having this single awesome police station mission where you actually supposed to ghost due to knockouts limit. And it has this awesome mission where you travel on rooftops of a city.

But I still can't help but to feel monotomy setting after the half of a game. After all, it still ends up too much with you blackjacking everybody you come across. Or maybe it's because of the plot. It starts nicely, with some conspiracy going on, but soon it's all same grey Mechanics, Mechanics, Mechanics, who lack some charm. Even though their leader is kinda awesome and robot carry it along, but the environment gets you after a while.
That, and I am still dissapoint that the plot didn't explore relationship between Hammerites and Mechanics. At least I never seen any actual conflict. Kinda hoped to see the clash of ideals ever since I overheard one of the very rare Hammerites complained in the second level. But oh well.

That, and in the last one third of a game it simply farts out. I don't know, it feels like the quality and excitement suddenly drops. Then again, Looking Glass studios was in deep financial trouble and was rushing out, I bet this is the impact to it. The Kidnap level is both boring looking and boring to play, in a cave with more mechanists, where you run all over the place to find the needed NPC. Not to mentioning that I had sudden framedrop because of some trouble with AI pathfinding, until I found the guard who was hogging game up.

Then you have two levels in a row that take place in same mansion, in both cased you enter it and exit in. The thing is that the first level of it feels like an earlier development version of the level, while the second time around it doesn't differenate enough to hold interest. Like plot-wise you sneak in to find a secret stairway toward the third floor so you knew where it is to snack masks on next day. After that you are supposed to leave yet you can venture futher into the third floor where you find many glitchy things, with flying decorations, misaligned models and you can even steal the already-present masks, but no one will care. As if you aren't supposed to be there.

Final level isn't bad though, at least on second try when I learned how to exploit big robots into blowing up themselves. And when I knew to take it slowly. Kinda like a little nightmare of steel, albeit I can see how some may decide that it goes too long, as well as being a challenge course. It's actually is quite awesome. But then the ending feels dissapointnig. It leaves you with no satisfication of victory and doesn't hype you up for next title. Just ends immeditly, with no music. Unlike the perfect Thief 1 ending.

But hey, I don't think that the main point of the games lies in ending. I would say that the Thief 2 is more than worth beating, even if it leaves you a bit sour. It's a Thief game, the one with complex levels, no hand-holding and more focus on stealth. And even though stealth core gameplay is still a bit on simple side, knocking everybody out, despite having excellent audio design that futhers gameplay, it's still a greatly enjoyable game.

La durée de vie est toujours immense non seulement parce que l'infiltration prend du temps (vraiment beaucoup, ça ne conviendra pas à tout le monde) et qu'il y a beaucoup d'exploration à faire (et beaucoup de secrets à découvrir) mais aussi parce que les niveaux sont toujours très grands. En plus, le jeu offre une rejouabilité certaine que ce soit pour tenter une approche alternative ou pour améliorer son temps ou obtenir un plus gros butin.

L'IA a plutôt un bon niveau et il faut vraiment se la jouer discrète en profitant des zones d'ombre, en se déplaçant silencieusement et en cachant toujours les corps des ennemis qu'on élimine. On doit toujours jouer avec l'oreille tendue pour écouter les déplacements des ennemis ou leurs dialogues souvent drôles. Le passage en force est toujours la dernière option et le jeu incite plutôt à relever la défi de finir l'aventure sans tuer personne voire sans frapper un seul ennemi (bourrins, passez votre chemin!).

Si l'essentiel du scénario est raconté lors des très jolies cinématiques entre les missions, l'histoire se dévoile aussi par bribes selon les indices qu'on récolte lors de notre exploration. Que ce soit des documents, des objets ou des conversations, tout ceci enrichit l'intrigue et l'univers et fourni parfois des indices importants pour la suite de l'aventure.

Une difficulté du jeu est qu'il y a des zones très très sombres où on ne voit rien du tout et dans lesquelles on doit se déplacer à l'aveuglette ou avec l'aide bien modeste de la carte ou des torches qui s'éteignent après quelques secondes. Ca peut être très énervant sur le moment d'être bloqué dans l'obscurité totale sans trouver d'issue mais il s'avère presque toujours qu'il y avait un moyen de mettre de la lumière grâce à un interrupteur très bien caché ou très éloigné. Mais ça renforce aussi le fait que le héros n'est pas un soldat suréquipé mais un modeste voleur.

Le jeu est disponible ici uniquement en anglais mais il existe un excellent patch FR et le tout tourne sans problème sous win8.

Vous l'aurez compris : à recommander aux joueurs qui apprécient de prendre le temps de profiter de leur liberté mais qui ne conviendra pas à ceux qui ont besoin d'être assistés comme dans la plupart des jeux actuels ou qui ne jurent que par l'action pure.

Thief 2 offre de l'infiltration pure comme peut-être jamais un jeu ne l'a proposé. Une référence absolue, une totale réussite. Avec comme apothéose une très complète mission finale d'anthologie.

20362544.review:
[b]Thief II is a first-person stealth game realeased back in March of 2000. It's set in a city, aptly named The City, with a steampunk aesthetic. You play as Garrett, a thief with a wide assortment of tools, weapons, and gadgets to assist him. [/b]

The minute you get in the first thing you'll probably do is change the controls. The default controls in this game are set up fairly differently than the average first-person game, but you'll have little-to-no trouble after setting them up. The graphics are pretty dated, even as far as 2000 is concerned.

The stealth mechanics of Thief are much more interesting than the average stealth system, based more around light and sound as opposed to the cone of vision that other stealth games tend to employ. Garrett decides to wear his clogs on every mission, so stepping on stone makes you much more obvious than stepping on something like a rug, while stepping on tile is a death sentence. The light gem at the bottom of the screen lights up to tell you if you're being lit up by the light around you, or is dark to show that you're completely in the shadows. Very rarely do games use lighting and sound as effectively as Thief does here.

The missions in the second Thief, as opposed to the original Thief, focus more around simple thievery instead of supernatural missions involving zombies and cultists. This is pretty subjective as to whether or not it's a pro or con, but I prefer the thievery. The original Thief is more of the same, but with more of the aforementioned zombies and cultists.

[list]
[h1]Pros[/h1]
[*]Lighting and sound are both fantastic, easily some of the best, even today.
[*]Interesting stealth system, only game to use anything comparable is Mark of the Ninja.
[*]The atmosphere is so thick it could give you lung cancer.
[*]More focus on thievery

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[*]Graphics are pretty bad, even going back to 2000.
[*]Less than friendly to newer players, but not impossible to get into
[*]Less focus on supernatural elements [/list]

[u][b]Final Thoughts[/b]:[/u]
It's easily one of the best stealth games to date. The original is preferable if you want more of the zombies and similar stuff, and Deadly Shadows is a little more forgiving. Overall, I'd reccomend it to anyone looking for an extremely fun and unique stealth system that's rarely contested, even to this day.

[b]Rating:[/b] 9.5/10

I didn't play the Thief games upon their initial release and so am not reviewing this through the rose-tinted glasses of nostalgia. But I can safely say that these games honestly do still hold up today.

Pros:
- Light/Dark system is a great mechanic and leads to the player paying more attention to their environment.
- Static map, some areas are missing and without an all encompassing minimap you are forced to be more cautious, unsure of what lies around each corner and this adds to the game's  tense atmosphere. 
- Your footsteps become louder when walking on harder floors such as marble, adds depth and makes you more observant of your surroundings.
- No zombies or supernatural elements (preference).
- Excellent level design, navigating is not a problem despite not having a full map or quest markers. This is because the levels are designed logically (as though they were not designed just for a game but to serve the purpose of the building e.g a mansion)  and loot is distibuted accordingly, e.g you can safely assume that there will be little to no loot in the servants quarters, but there will more than certainly be something valuable in the nobles quarters.
- Tells the story through level design and gameplay instead of directly through a cutscene or text.
- You can't choose to go in all guns blazing, you die quickly (2 sword hits) and thus feel more vunerable and this creates tension. You aren't invincible, their is no second option to just fight your way in. Only through the patience and intelligence of the player can Garrett succeed, as you play you become a better thief- not through "levelling up"- you are never given any notification of your progress by the game (this is a good thing), Garrett stays his same vunerable self throughout the whole game, but you the player learn how to handle yourself: which areas are low/high risk, when to blackjack guards, where to hide etc ... This is extremely rewarding as by the end of the game you (the player) have gone from an amateur burglar to a masterthief, this progression of the player instead of the character is extremely rewarding and makes you feel like you are truly getting more skillful- this progression is expressed not through a number or a level and Garrett doesn't become more powerful as you play, your growth is shown in the way you play the game.
- Amazing soundtrack.

Cons:
- May be too dark and hard too see for some.
- Not the greatest voice acting.
- Graphics whilst not awful do not compare with those of newer titles.

You owe it to yourself to experience this masterpiece.

How does one rave about one of their all time favorite games without sounding like a raving lunatic?

Look, there are 4 (sorta) Thief games.  If each of them gets 10 points (so a total of 40) and you break it up here's the ranking:

Theif II: The Metal Age 50/10
Thief: The Dark Project (Gold) 10/10
Thief: Deadly Shadows 5/10
Thief -25/10

But that includes 3 stories for another time.

I do have to mention Dark Project/Gold briefly since Thief II would not exist without it.  It really is a fine game in its own right, the best Stealth Game up to that point. You may get seen and want to fight your way out (or have to I suppose) and you are not entirely without resources.  However, you CAN get through it without ever swinging your blade. Thief 2: TMA is everything a sequel should be, and more! Though  it doesn't have the same 'horror' element that the first game had, it's still very atmospheric with an incredible ambience that will suck you in to its dark, treacherous world and it won't let go until Karras closes the doors to Soulforge, forever sealing his fate! (yeah, more on Soulforge later).

All of the original Thief gameplay mechanics are still in place w/ added features: the stealth is in full effect with deeply complex missions and large maps that allow for multiple routes to completing objectives, all the sexy arrow types you loved from the first game are back (now with vine arrows), all of your original gadgets are back (now with scouting orbs, and in rare cases explosive devices), there are new enemy types (most notably female soldiers) and of course a new antagonist (alas, Constantine is no more, but Karras is easily just as much of a douche as he was, so it's cool, and there's even a ghost pirate at one point if you can find him and his glorious pirate booty....um....let me rephrase that, I mean his treasure).  Oh, and I almost forgot one of the coolest upgrades, the cinematics between missions (some play out like storyboard drawings but others are actual cinematics and there's sorta one when you die too, but obviously that's not as cool as the others).

Now back to the final mission, Sabotage at Soulforge, Karras' stronhold, his HQ, the locus of his nefarious activities, yeah you get the point.  Being a final mission you'd expect some level of challenge and complexity and Soulforge certainly doesn't disappoint. But seriously, this mission for me was so vast and complex that I spent nearly a quarter of my total game time wandering its darkened corridors with like negative 5 hitpoints at some points, all while trying to figure out where I should go next and how not to get killed by Karras' mechanoid creations. After finally beating this mission, I almost felt like I couldn't recall an earlier point in the game but Soulforge.  It was as though the entire game took place in this one hub-like area.  Mentally, I was nearly defeated by this final quest but I persevered in the end and so Karras can suck it!

If you like Thief you'll love this one just as much, if not more so.  Get it on sale when you can but as far as classics go, it's a must own even if you have to pay the full price and there is so much depth and challenge that you'll be glad you made the purchase in the end.

15819813.review:
I'll be honest, I preferred the first one. While here the equipment selection has been improved, the areas expanded, and the missions more varied, I felt that The Metal Age was a bit off in terms of atmosphere and occasional design flaws, on top of bugs similar to those of The Dark Project, which I have just come to assume are inherent problems of the Dark Engine, which both games utilized.

The levels are large, and use a color and texture palette more believable than that of the first game. Personally, I liked the fantasy-looking themes of The Dark Project, compared to the industrial feeling of The Metal Age.
More space brings more to do, and while more challenges are welcome, the gameplay feels weak when the levels only allow one entrance to a particular location, and this will happen much more here than in its predecessor. As much as I hate hand-holding, I hate a lack of direction a tiny bit more. The Dark Project was good at giving the player direction through in-game literature and dialogue, and this sort of help is not as available here.

I wouldn't have such a problem with confusing level design if I was given more freedom to explore, but enemies are quite plentiful in this entry, along with many types that are only susceptible to explosive weaponry, limiting possible approaches and damaging that appeal of the game. While human opponents are usually easily dealt with, the mechanical enemies frequently chew up inventory items, often resulting in death when there are just too many to either destory or avoid.

The inventory holds a larger variety of equipment, but due to the sheer volume it can be a pain to navigate when having to do so quickly. The usefulness of some items has changed. The game seems intent on giving me plenty of water arrows, even though most of the light sources are electric lamps, and there is very little blood to ever have to clean. Fire arrows are much more helpful, but now quite rare. Maps are a big improvement over the previous game. Rather than being given my general location, I am now told which room I am in, which is helpful in areas where the rooms look the same.

Overall, I enjoyed it, but due to its difficult-to-manage size, I felt like it lacked some of the cohesion present in The Dark Project.

15394378.review:
Certainly the greatest stealth game of all time......
Sequels usually are worse or hit the same beats as the original, only maybe changing the criticisms directed at the original. Thief II is pretty much a revamped Thief 1, feeling more like a mappack than a sequel.
It is, however, a much better thought-out game and feels much, much more secure in its concept and execution than The Dark Project. For starters, the levels are 100% dedictated to stealth and they feel a lot more fun to explore for it. Gone are the clunky combat sections and in place of that is fantastic level design that seems a lot more interested in attempting to replicate the experience of stealing from a rich guy's mansion or from a bank than the mystical weirdness from the many levels from the original. Levels also feel a lot bigger, with many sections and many, many different ways to explore them.
In terms of artstyle, this is Thief 1 with the occasional higher quality textures and the occasional better looking models, but neither Thief is really easy on the eyes, so a lot of that extra goes unnoticed.
Thief II's plot manages to be even better than the original, the focus still on Nature vs Science, but this time with Science being the main opponent and having an interesting (with an extremely annoying voice) antagonist that keeps you on your toes at every single opportunity he gets.
For it's more focused effort, the game feels a lot more repetitive than the original as the many city scenarios don't feel as alien as the organic-based levels, the contrast not as strong.
It is, in my opinion, for the best and Thief 2 is one of those sequels, that doesn't add or change much, but it doesn't need to, because for what it does, it does better than any other game out there.

     A proto je Garrett kontaktován naší známou Viktorií, lesní paní. V tu chvíli se rozjede akce jako letící vlak a příběh nabírá na otáčkách. Kradení zlaťáků a šperků ustupuje v plnění prazvláštních úkolů, které snad povedou k objevení nové a děsivé zbraně, kterou Karras stvořil ve jménu nejvyššího Stavitele, a se kterou se pokusí vyhladit lidstvo i přírodu.

     Jedna z mála her, ve které je druhý díl opravdu lepší, než díl první. Thief 2 The Metal Age staví na tom nejlepším, co se do jedničky vešlo. Opět se setkáme s velmi promyšleným příběhem. Městem plným rozhovorů a knih a poznámek a všelijakých odkazů, které hráče vtáhnou do atmosféry a děje.
     Máme perfektní hudební doprovod. Obecně zvuková stránka této hry je naprosto famózní. Od jedničky přibyla schopnost poslouchat za dveřmi, což opravdu hodně pomůže sledovat pohyb kráčejících nebo jen odkašlávajících strážných.
     Světelný model prodělal jen velmi málo změn. Opět se setkáváme s krystalem, který září podle toho, jak se v něm odráží světlo okolí a tím vás informuje o tom, jak moc jste viditelní pro své nepřátele. Animace zůstaly stejné a to je jen dobře. Ponurá atmosféra a děj odehrávající se pouze jako stínové divadlo je prostě perfetkní.
     Co je nové, tak to jsou nové modely. Nové postavy, věci, vybavení  (schopnost zoomu) a hlavně nová architektura, která je více postavena na detailu, než v předchozím díle. Nové je také samotné kradení. Věcí k ukradnutí je totiž všude mnohem více. A s tím si můžete opravdu vyhrát.
     Co ovšem zůstalo, to je těch pár chyb. Stále je prazvláštní AI, které někdy prostě jedná přehnaně (když probudíte zvukem šperháku strážného), nebo naopak nedostatečně (když strážný projde prostě přímo přes vás, aniž by cokoliv udělal). Pohyb po kovu nebo dlaždicích lze zase překlikat tak, aby nebylo nic slyšet. Ničeho nového jsem si nevšiml.
     Když ale vezmeme v potaz, že hra obsahuje kolem 40 hodin slušné zábavy s nárůstem obtížnosti, je vydávána s vlastním editorem misí a díky dlouholeté podpoře je i pro dnešní počítače hezky udržovanou (servisní balíčky pro nejnovější Windows), domnívám se, že je hra naprostým klenotem každé herní sbírky. 10/10

14475200.review:
Next in line in the Thief series, here I am. I have never played any of the games of Thief, though I have always wanted to. I just finished the first game and wrote a review for it, and now have finished the second. The very first Thief disappointed me very much, but that was all due to the level design, which ruined the whole experience for me. However, I was still greatly interested in the world's atmosphere and story, so I was hopeful with this game and came in with a neutral outlook.

Thief II greatly increased my expectations through the first two-thirds of the game, but quickly disappointed me again with the last 5 missions and the ending. Firstly, just to brush through everything else, as I don't need to say much more here than I did with the first Thief:

+ The story and the atmosphere given by it is just as engaging.
+ The graphics were better than the first game's, and the world mostly looked like it was put together better in each level. The cinematics were pretty much the same in style, however.
+ Garrett is still just as likable of a character!
+ The sound effects are mostly similar, and the voice acting is still well done, except for Karras, which I will go into more detail later.
+ The gameplay mechanics are mostly the same as well, not too much new, though I enjoyed things like the robotic cameras you can throw.

In the end, most of the above is rather the same, though slightly improved in one way or another. Nothing too drastically new in those areas... but the level design, now that was so much better! Based on the first two-thirds of the game, I have to say that the levels were (mostly) great, so much better than 90% of the levels in the first game.

The first level was an interesting start, especially neat for clearing a path for an NPC. The second, however, was pretty bad and generic again, scaring me that the game would be the same. The storage area was nothing special, and the design of having to repeatedly go to the office, punch in a code, and go back out so many times was just bad.

But afterwards, the game picked back up very well. I liked every mission up to and including Life of the Party, though the Eavesdropping/Bank missions were nothing too special. Ambush was actually a very good mission for me. I enjoyed running throughout the city, trying to weave my own path back to my place, creeping around. Life of the Party was my other favorite mission, sneaking around on the rooftops being my favorite part. Before that, Trail of Blood was interesting as well, mostly in the environment and the ghosts you kept encountering.

None of those levels were really that confusing as in the first game either. They were no longer wide open, empty areas. Instead, you could get a better grasp on where you were for the most part, and I could always keep track of what I was doing, never getting bored.

Then came the last third of the game, back to terrible. From the first Cavador mission forward, I didn't enjoy the environments anymore, nor did the levels keep me entertained. Even worse, the Casing the Joint mission was a generic build for the most part. I mean, I was interested with the secret paths throughout the place at first, but to be honest, they wore out pretty quickly, as the mission was such a pain of trial-and-error, more so than any other mission. Then the immediately next mission throws you back into the same exact mansion with basically no difference! What a pain, and what a terrible design decision.

And for the finale, Soulforge wasn't linear like in the original game, but it wasn't interesting either. The first room you start in looked cool, then everything else was just generic looking and full of robots. I understand that it fits the story (the Metal Age!) but it didn't make me want to keep going. And that ending cinematic, wow! The ending of the first game wasn't the greatest, but still much better than this one. It seems that Looking Glass really didn't know how to end games, between System Shock 2 and these two Thief games.

As a side note, mentioned above, Karras had the worst voice of the game. So terrible. He sounded like he just had this nasal jelly mass stuck in his throat. There is some weird, annoying cartoon character that it reminded me of, but I can't remember for the life of me, at the moment. I know that Stephen Russell did the voice and he also does many others, included Garrett's! But Karras is so different, and literally I had to mute my sound any time his voice was prominent throughout the game. I can't really say there have been many voices that have caused me to do that, and it was only slightly worse that all of the robots spout his voice too.

In the end, I was really impressed with about half of the game, neutral for a little piece, and then very disappointed with the last third. Do I recommend that people play the game? Sure. I enjoyed it for a good while, much more than I did the first game. I will never play the first game again, whereas I might play some of the missions here again.

Now, I am onto the third game, Deadly Shadows. Let's see how it goes!

13277859.review:
Thief 2: The Metal Age, developped by (the long since defunct) Looking Glass Studios, is the direct sequel to 1998's Thief:The Dark Project. To summarize, you play as master thief Garret (voiced by the great Stephen Russel) who is trying to unravel The City's new religious order, The Mechanists (the replacement of the first game's Hammerites, who believed in the Creator and that industrial construction was the way to keep evil influences, such as the Trickster (a Pan-esque God who worships chaos and nature) at bay. If you don't understand you should check out the first game, it's great!) and their leader, Father Karras, the likes of which are inventing new mechanical innovations in security and industry (robot guards, cameras,etc). 

The core stealth gameplay is still here from Thief 1, with the ability to deal with guards either lethally or nonlethally (avoiding or blackjacking them) and either playstyles are sufficiently suitable for every mission. This is primarily because the level design in Thief 2 (like its predecessor) contains many hidden paths and secrets to find and explore to deal with mission objectives and secure the most amount of loot possible. Also with new items such as invisibility potions and old ones such as noisemaker arrows (used to distract guards and clear paths), as previously stated, both playstyles are equally supported in the game. 

The stealth mechanics are still as great as the first game, with the "light gem" still in effect( flashing white if you are visible; dark if you are not), the ability to lean around corners to see guards/ cameras/etc. and the aforementioned items to facilitate being stealthy. One improvement I loved from Thief 2 is the change of setting for the missions, from looting ancient crypts and supernatural dimensions( still awesome but not very thief-like) to looting actual mansions and houses (especially the amount of loot in every level, with multiple areas to scour and explore). And whilst these houses and mansions may not look too good, i feel the art style has a certain charm to it.  

Another reason why i enjoy this game? Its story and atmosphere, Garret's tale and The City's backstory is thoroughly established in the pre mission cutscenes and books and texts found throughout levels. And the game's soundtrack is simply amazing, with chilling sweeping synths and general dark tones, the game's soundtrack gives the player a sense of always being watched, of potentially being hunted down, which gives the game's world such a distinctive feeling of ambience and general eerieness. But these are just my thoughts so feel free to check this amazing game out if you'd like, but I'd recommend checking out the first game beforehand, then diving into The Metal Age's world.

Представьте себе вы проходите город, в котором надо пройти из точки А в точку Б исключительно по крышам. Cokolwiek masz, jest już moje!

Ogólnie - Grę zrobiło studio Looking Glass Technologies a wydało Square-Enix / Eidos. Thief 2: The Metal Age jest kontynuacją pierwszej części gry, która odniosła duży sukces na całym świecie stając się nowym gatunkiem gier, który został nazwany FPS - first person sneaker.

Grafika - Gra jak jej poprzedniczka nadal jest na silniku Dark Engine ale zostały dodane poprawione 16 bitowe tekstury wysokiej rozdzielczości oraz dynamiczne oświetlenie.

Gameplay - Thief 2 nadal jest skradaczem z widokiem dla pierwszej osoby, jedynie co się zmieniło to zmniejszenie elementów fantastycznych które denerwowały większość graczy (Sam do nich należę).

Fabuła - Złodziej Garrett po pokonaniu Szachraja powraca do swoich zwyczajnych zajęć - kradzieżą kosztowności od bogatych mieszkańców Miasta lub pozyskiwaniem cennych przedmiotów na zlecenie.

Okazuje się jednak, że życie złodzieja stało się teraz cięższe niż dotychczas, zreformowana Straż Miejska, z szeryfem Gormanem Truartem na czele, wzmożyła wysiłki mające na celu łapanie przestępców pokroju Garretta. Ponadto dochodzi do dziwnych zniknięć żebraków, prostytutek i biednych ludzi ogółem, o których nikt nie będzie pamiętał.

Metropolia ulega znacznemu zmodernizowaniu, pojawiają się wynalazki nowej grupy religijnej, zwącej się Mechanistami, która pod przywództwem niejakiego Karrasa oderwała się od Młotodzierżców, których pozycjach uległa drastycznemu oslabieniu. Mechaniści przyczynili się do znacznego rozwoju Miasta, ich wynalazki są w użytku powszechnym, także m.in Straży Miejskiej, zaczyna jednak powoli brakować zielonych miejsc w Mieście. Wszelkie skwery z drzewami są przez nich po prostu likwidowane.

Garrett w tym czasie wykonuje kilka zleceń, m.in dla starego znajomego - Bazyla a także dokonuje włamania w magazynach portowych oraz infiltruje jeden z posterunków Straży Miejskiej. Wkrótce ściąga na siebie ich uwagę, ledwo ucieka z zastawionej na niego zasadzki. Wkrótce kontaktują się z nim Strażnicy. W swojej siedzibie ostrzegają go przez nadejściem Wieku Metalu, z czym powiązani są Mechaniści. Równowaga ponownie zostaje zachwiana...

Muzyka/Dźwięk - Jest jej o wiele więcej niż w The Dark Projekt ale i tak przez połowę gry słyszymy tylko swoje kroki lub odgłosy otoczenia.

OCENA OGÓLNA
- Grafika 8/10 Nadal trzyma poziom 
- Gameplay 8/10 To wciąż ten sam Thief 
- Fabuła 8/10 Rozwija się powoli
- Muzyka/Dźwięk 8/10 Mogło być lepiej 

PODSUMOWANIE
Druga gra z serii Thief jest taka jaka powinna być, każdy fan serii oraz skradanek powinien sobie w ten tytuł zagrać.

Pozdrawiam Lanxis

12155925.review:
Thief II: The Metal Age sets the high water mark for stealth gaming.  Bar none.  No game before or since can compare to the immersiveness of this game and it's fine-tuned mechanics.  It manages to mix the fantasy, strategy and adventure aspects of the first with a more prescient storyline than the first Thief game.  The first game was an excellent stealth game that occasionally drifted too far into Tomb Raider territory with it's platformy style missions, devious traps and creature threats.  The fact that Eidos was the publisher of both Thief and Tomb Raider, and that one of the missions had you raiding an underground tomb frought with booby traps and monsters, ought to tell you something.  Thief 2 , thankfully, focuses on the strengths of the stealth system and makes that the core of the game and not just an aspect of it.  That's not to say you won't be jumping across ravines and encountering creatures, but the heist-pulling, pick-pocketing and blackjacking really comes into thier own in Thief 2.  I've read that the developers created the missions of the first game to suit the plot, while the missions of the second were produced first with the plot retrofitted.  In any case, the levels are larger and more complex than the first.

The graphics had gotten a slight bump from the first game with higher poly models, better texturing and weather effects.  They even added dithering to the hardware renderer, which was a nice addition.  It did have the effect of dampening the deep shadows that were such a part of the first game, but it generally made the game more pleasing to the eye. 

The sound design is, again, excellent.  Sound propagation is one of the core facets of gameplay.  Listening to footsteps draw near or fade into the distance allow you to judge from your hiding place in the shadows whether or not you can risk stepping into lit areas.  Leaning against doors to listen to conversations or the presence of sounds in the next room allow you to determine if opening a door is wise or not.  Sound is fundamental to this game.  You will not be able to play this game successfully while blasting Megadeth or Slayer.  Just not happening.  And that's one of the things that makes this game so damn immersive.  You are literally concerned with the environment both visually and aurally at all times.  It sucks you in.  

There are some new gadgets in this game.  Garrett lost an eye in the first game, and that has been replaced by a mechanical eye that can zoom in and out like a telescope.  A new object called the Scouting Orb allows you to take a peak over walls or around corners without exposing yourself.  There are also new potions and a new arrow:  the vine arrow.  Similar to the rope arrow, but it can "stick" to things rope arrows can't, like metal gratings.

The design went from a predominantly dark age style steampunk in Thief 1 to a predominantly Victorian era style steampunk in Thief 2, in much of it's architecture.  Actually, art deco also makes an appearance as part of the design of buildings operated by a faction that's new to Thief 2, the Mechanists.   The European old world oozes in these games.  In fact, many of the textures from Thief 1 and Thief 2 were from photos of architecture taken by the developers while vacationing in Europe.   The overall design is pretty immaculate.  

The first two Thief games share a cult status, along with System Shock2 (uses the same game engine and made by some of the same people), as games of remarkable vision and quality.  They are all lauded as excellent games by the gaming press and continue to make the top # lists.  The gameplay transcends gaming.  To play this game is to embark on an existential and  metaphysical experience.  This game seems to attract a higher-brow gaming audience.  There is a community forum that has been the stomping grounds of its players since the games were released.  They have created hundreds of fan missions to play; you can find it here:  http://www.ttlg.com/forums/forum.php

Here you can get a community made patch that updates the rendering of the game and allows for some nice effects, like bloom, while also fixing a number of leftover bugs:  http://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=131106

Here you can get a high resolution patch that updates some models, textures and also adds a numbder of new effects to the game:  http://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=144312

Here you can read about and find fan missions to play:  http://www.ttlg.com/forums/forumdisplay.php?f=100

WOW is it different than "THIEF" (the newest one, not part of the original trilogy). It's in a league of its own. Strategy, timing, and pure stealth are key in the Thief trilogy. I miss games back in the day. In the bank level, the first time I played it, it took me just over 4 hours to beat. That's just one of many levels. What made so many older games awesome was that some games had absolutely gargantuan levels, and in the Thief trilogy they had a dozen ways of being completed, increasing replayability, whereas games today tend to be so linear, with the exception of a rare few.

Enjoy it!

'Thief 2' is like 'Doom 2' in the sense that it's the exact same game only better. The core gameplay remains almost entirely unchanged, the engine is identical, and there is only a minor difference in graphics. 

This game very easy to sell. Did you like the great voice acting, excellent level-desing, outstanding atmosphere, and the innovative, stealth-based gameplay of the first game? Did you hate the levels that featured unkillable zombies and various other creatures? Well, there are hardly any zombies or creatures (you have to go out of your way to find them, and they're very easy to avoid) the voice acting, gameplay, and atmosphere are the same - and the levels are EVEN BIGGER. Thief 3, Thief 4, and Dishonoured can go sit in the corner and cry. 

One level in Thief 2 has you sneak through an entire town (you can tip-toe on the rooftops, or you can creep through the shadows of the streets) - which culminates in raiding a six-storey high mansion. This is without loading screens, and there are millions of hidden nooks and crannies where you can find various goodies to steal. Another level has you travel through a ruined Aztec city, and another a jungle filled with treehouses. Aside from perhaps 'Deus Ex', this game has the largest and most detailed levels in gaming history (and by 'detailed' I mean rooms with furniture and books you can read, and fireplaces that lead to secret passageways - not 'detailed' in a graphical sense) 

Whilst I recommend playing 'Thief 1', and even 'Thief 3' (avoid 'Thief 4') if you must only play one Thief game...make it this one.

I don't often write reviews, only under the circumstance whether the game was incredibly enjoyable, or so terrible you'd rather pull your own teeth. I wish I had the same experience as the other players who write, "this was one of the best games I've ever played", but I didn't and I can't fake that I did. I feel like I could gripe forever about it but I'll keep it short (I'll try). I did play Thief Gold and enjoyed it a lot. While there were some things I wasn't a fan of, I was able to get over them and still really enjoy the game. Hoping for the same experience in Thief II, I was let down. My biggest gripe of the game, which sounds silly until you play it, is the game is SO. MOTHER. EFFING. DARK. This alone, ruined the game for me. And what held me back from finding it was that it was hidden in the darkest, most pitch black area of a random room. I can't harp on it enough, no matter how much I adjusted the gamma option, or my brightness on my monitor, it never improved. Again sounds silly, but I was physically incapable of finding these things because of it being so dark. The first game was dark too, but not to the extent to where you actually can't see what's ahead of you. There are flares added to the game, but they really don't offer much help. It brightens things up about 1 foot around you, and then disappears after 10 seconds or so.

There are other things that bother me about this game, but that is the main one. I almost feel like that if that one thing didn't affect me so much, I'd be able to look past the other things like I did in the first game. I was so determined to beat this game and just completely remove it from my computer. To be stuck in a level for 4-5 hours only to find out that you need to walk through a door in a room you've been in several times already, is something I never want in a game again. Thief II is a steampunk stealth game.
It's a Singleplayer only game. 
Release date: 21.03.2000

Graphics:    6/10

The graphics are ok for its release date. In comparison to the prequel it's only a slight improvement, but I think they could've made it a little bit better than they actually did. Like the prequel they managed to create an awesome atmosphere with the "poor" graphics and effects. One reason I just gave 6/10 is that most of the game looks 1:1 exactly the same like
Thief Gold.

Sound:     6/10

The sounds are quite good and the voice actors are doing a great job. Some sounds are really annoying (robots for example). Like in Thief Gold there is nearly no music. I know it's not necessary, but I still miss it.

Level design:     7/10

The level design is just as good as in the prequel. You can search for secrets and have more than one way to reach your goal. The atmosphere is fitting and the levels are well structured.
Except for one level, namely the last one. The last level is so frustrating. If you want to sneak the whole way through then you get detected the slow way. If you want to rush through you get detected fast. That is the only difference and the reason why I skipped the last level. And this last level degrades the Level design by 2 points: 9/10 => 7/10.

Gameplay/Handling/Equipment:     8/10

The good points: Like in the prequel you have a really nice arsenal for a thief. Plenty of arrowtypes, the flashbomb for your escape and so on. You still must get used to the controls but when you know how to play it you will like it. The playstyle remains pretty much like it was in the prequel. You sneak around, steal stuff, knock out enemies, etc..
The bad point: No improvements at all.

Enemies/AI:     6/10

Well the guards search for you if you are too loud and act really authentic. But robots act totally random and I don't get the point why they made them so annoying. Sure it's no problem to disable them but still I don't like the idea of them. They didn't improve the AI from Thief Gold to Thief 2 so I just give 6/10.

Story:     4/10

Maybe it's just me but I don't like the story. It's boring and I miss the "magical" part of it. The target is a guy who wants to kill people with poison and created robots to protect himself. I don't even know how to make it sound better.

Critic summary:     6,2/10

Personal fun rating:     7/10     [good game]

All in all a good game, but the developers didn't make real improvements. I recommend the game if you played Thief Gold, otherwise I don't. Since the game isn't very expensive: Give it a try.

9484108.review:
Nostalgia really is a funny thing.

I've been a Looking Glass Studios fan since the 90's with System Shock 2, and a Thief fan for a long time. Thief II: The Metal Age (the sequel to the critically-praised Thief: The Dark Project) brings players back into the world of master thief Garrett, this time with a bunch of new missions and antagonist in the form of Karras, the leader of the Mechanists.

The one thing I loved most about this game was that the scale just felt bigger in (almost every way). While I still have an issue with the fact that roughly half the levels are strictly linear, the missions that open up to you (like "Stonemarket First Bank", "Life of the Party" and "Masks") offer a wide array of alternate routes and secret passages to accomplish your goals, as well as give a far grander sense of the City and the threat Karras poses to its inhabitants.

Likewise, the variety of weapons and items you can acquire is great and allows for lots of experimentation, although (since I'm a purist) I still stuck to water arrows for the majority of the game.

Admittedly, I found much more joy in the levels where I could pick off guards at will with hit-and-run tactics. I think it's fair to say that the AI in this game alternates between hypersensitive and woefully inept. When the guards aren't aggro-ing on you from far distances, they're complete morons in combat. It is exceptionally easy to take advantage of the combat system. When a sword-wielding guard runs at you, walk backwards and swing like mad, or circle-strafe and hit his back. Bow-wielders are an automatic win - just mash the attack button if you get one cornered. The only real challenge came from the Mechanist robots and groups of enemies, which sometimes stacked up in doors and got stuck or ran around the mansion in the "Masks" mission chasing me (all that was missing was the Benny Hill music).

Likewise, the voice acting is either really good (in the case of Garrett's voice actor and some of the minor antagonists) or near-laughable (the nobles, who sound like they're reading from a script). I couldn't take Karras seriously as a villain because of his nasally voice, which made me laugh more than get freaked out whenever I heard his voice.

I vaguely remembered a lot of buzz and praise for "Life of the Party", which sees Garrett take to the rooftops to rob every building in sight and infiltrate Karras' tower, Angelwatch - and that mission did not disappoint. Easily the best in the game, it had everything I consider to be so great about the genre - lots of expansive areas and alternate routes to take, lots of secrets and hidden goodies to find, great level design, the works. I wish more of the missions had those kinds of additional areas or features to make them worth replaying, because I didn't feel much compulsion to go back and do much besides replay the missions that were either "loot everything" or "steal and/or kill everything".

All in all, though, Thief II is still a standout in the stealth genre. I haven't played Deadly Shadows yet (as of this writing), but the improvement in scope in this game makes me excited to see what's next.

When it comes to the pinnacle of stealth gaming, some say Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory, some say Hitman: Blood Money, and some even have the audacity to say Assassin's Creed. While they're all worthy contenders, Thief 2 stands fully erect as the throbbing crown jewel of an underappreciated genre. 

They just don't make many games like this anymore. There are 15 glorious levels--each of which can take anywhere between 30 minutes to three hours depending on your level of Kleptomania. Even in 2014, I am still amazed at how goddamn huge the levels are, and the sheer amount stuff hidden in every nook and cranny. Sure, on a graphical level the game hasn't aged well at all, but from a gameplay standpoint, this game was (and still is) WAY ahead of it's time. Dishonored pointed its pinky in the right direction, but still wasn't able to capture the sheer size and replayability of this game. There are levels within levels within levels. It blows my mind. 

Anyway, I'm surprised you made it this far in my review and haven't purchased this game yet. You're getting easily 20+ hours from this badboy...and that's undercutting it by a lot. This is the template for how to make a perfect stealth game. Period.

Thief II is a classic stealth game from a time when games were meant to actually challenge the player, force him to think, and punish him should he act hastily. This game will not hold your hand at all; there are no objective markers, no bullshit x-ray vision that pervades modern stealth games, and no option to play like it's a generic shooter. The game is very non-linear, with multiple pathways and options for stealth, and even some secret passages for one with a clever mind and sharp eye. The ultimate goal, however, always remains the same: steal some priceless artifact and escape, leaving no trace. 

The few downsides I can think of with this game just stem from it's age: the graphics are very dated, and the AI isn't very advanced, but the latter can be negated by thinking that the game's main challenge comes from the environment, not the guards. In addition, the Dark Engine that this game runs on is a little buggy, especially when it comes to dismounting from a ladder and climbing up objects, but it shouldn't impede your enjoyment too much. 

If you enjoyed Dishonored (which was inspired by the Thief franchise) or the real Splinter Cell games (the series up until Double Agent), you can't go wrong with this game.

Собственно, прямой сиквел первой части, выглядящий вполне типично для того времени: практически ни каких изменений в геймплее, механике и интерфейсе - только доработка, исправление недочётов и доведение до ума некоторых вещей. Пожалуй, в этом плане нам большего и не надо. Ведь интересные уровни и сюжет, а также внедрение свежих идей куда важнее. И их есть у Thief 2.
Если не вдавться в подробности и различные нюансы сюжета, то можно сказать лишь то, что игра, как и 1-я часть, начинается с типичных воровских будней Гаррета, решения простых бытовых проблем. Ну и, собственно, "настоящий" сюжет начинается опять-таки где-то только на середине игры.
Что же касается мира игры - то он, так сказать, обновился до версии 2.0. Та самая сладкая парочка - стимпанк и технопанк,- теперь уже свободно разгуливают по улицам и строениям Города, крепко держась за руки. Притом чувствуют они себя настолько свободно, что зачастую пораждают такие штуковины, которые и нашему-то миру ещё толком неподвластны.
В отличие от первой части, здесь игра уже концентрируется по большей мере именно на самом Городе и его учреждениях. В связи с чем всех тех мест и существ "не из мира сего" мы уже практически не встретим (повторюсь - практически, ибо припасены кое-какие сюрпризы). Тем не менее игра нам преподносит другой ничуть не менее интересный контент. В частности, мы знакомимся с устройством местной цивилизации - и аналогий с нашей современностью вам не миновать :) Впрочем шнырять по Городу теперь стало куда опаснее: ведь время идёт - и технологии не дремлют. Однако подстроиться под "новые стандарты" не так уж и сложно - дело привычки. Тем более инвентарь Гаррета тоже пополнился всякими новыми полезными (и не очень) штуками.
Короче говоря, вторая часть предстала перед нами такой же интересной и занимательной, как и первая. И главное - она не стала повторять уже пройденные пути, а показала нам совершенно новые области вселенной Thief.

Также грешно не помянуть Looking Glass Studios, которая была прикрыта через пару месяцев после выпуска игры, а вместе с ней так и не появившуюся на свет "позолоченную" версию 2-го "Вора". В Thief II Gold планировалось добавить по меньшей мере 4 новых уровня. Зачатки этих уровней ныне присутствуют в сети. И даже нашлись умельцы, осмелившиеся доработать весь невыпущенный контент. Однако дальше одного уровня дело чё-то не пошло...

А вот что действительно пошло как надо - так это неофициальный аддон ко 2-й части под названием Thief 2X: Shadows of the Metal Age, вышедший в 2005 году. Впрочем, неофициальный он только формально - на деле же сие творение выглядит как полноценное официальное дополнение. Выглядит очень качественно, и соблюдает все принципы оригинальных частей. Само собой лишь нахождением в рамках, сколоченных в Looking Glass, дело тут не обошлось - и дополнение предлагает нам немало "отсебятины" (в хорошем смысле слова). В первую очередь стоит отметить, что сюжет игры завязан на абсолютно новом персонаже, и действия игры происходят на абсолютно новых локациях (правда, однажды нам-таки придётся пройтись уже по знакомой территории) - притом сделаны они качественно и интересно; далее - игра просто переполнена новыми текстами и историями, часть из которых так или иначе пересекается с основной историей Thief; добавлено несколько новых изобретений, отлично дополняющих стим/техно-панковскую базу; присутствует и множество новых интересных "девайсов" (один из них, например, способен изменять действие некоторых стрел - то бишь количество видов элементальных стрел в игре увеличено!). Из минусов же можно отметить в целом слегка банальный сюжет. Однако в плане деталей и различных поворотов, а также некоторых локальных сюжетных линий, он довольно интересный. В итоге хочется отметить, что "официальность" данного аддона навязывает не только количество и качество нового контента - но и то, что в нём нет ни единого расхождения с основными канонами серии! И это при том-то, что игра только так ссылается на различные действия и персонажей оригинала. От-так-то.
В общем, если вы решили пройти всю серию Thief - то данное дополнение ни в коем случае не проходите стороной! Потому что это ещё одна освещённая область во вселенной Thief (а ещё потому что главная героиня весьма привлекательна и... тсс!.. даже раскрыта тема сисек (не у героини) :D).

When Thief II released, I had probably already spent over 300 hours (re)playing Thief: The Dark Project and Thief: Gold. Shortly after its release, I rebuilt my PC and dove in. The graphics were much improved from the first games, and the story was even better. The missions were even more expansive this time, and replaying the game always led to finding something new. 

What made this game even more brilliant, was the opening of the Dark Engine to the users who wanted to mod/level build. Looking Glass Studios closed shortly after the release of Thief II and the sequel wasn't produced until 2004. In that period of downtime, hundreds of new, fan-made, missions were created and distributed in online communities like the Circle of Stone and Shadow. Some were better than others. And just a few may have been better than the game itself. In fact, one of the fan missions was so good, the developer was hired by Eidos to work on Thief III. Moreover, some fan mission developers ended up joining forces to release their own, unofficial sequel named Thief2x. 

The game itself had its own replay value, but the fans who made these missions and mods increased the value tenfold. 

Thief II is a must play. I'd definitely recommend playing Thief: The Dark Project or Thief: Gold first. When you're done, it's worth doing the investigation to find these fan-made missions and play them too.

For Thief II, you could mostly just take my Thief Gold review, and then copy/paste all of the pros overtop of all of the cons. Thief II plays mostly the same as Thief Gold. Same graphics, same controls, same first-person view. What they did change, however, makes all the difference.

Thief Gold had a number of really fun missions featuring Garrett prowling around a house or opera hall or what-have-you, knocking out guards and discovering secret passages, and those were great. But it spent just as much time knee deep in zombies, apemen, giant bugs, bugmen, ghosts, confusing labyrinths, caves, and situations where you almost HAVE to fight your way out if you're not super-great at the game.

For Thief II, the devs looked at what players did and did not enjoy, and they made a game that is better in almost all respects. Save for a single Thief Gold-esque level with some apemen (which is rather forgiving compared to TG, and a fascinating level overall), there are only maybe a couple of any particular monster, and most of them are avoidable. The only new monster type I can recall gave me the biggest (and most enjoyable) fright of anything in either game. The majority of levels take place in sane man-made structures; homes, a bank, a surprisingly modern police station, and a few missions taking place across entire sections of The City. Thus the game now flows better, being less of a half-forced monster combat game, and more about sneaking around, bludgeoning unsuspecting jerks, and looting every last inch of each level.

As a result of the titular Metal Age, Thief II also now includes cameras, robots, turrets,  and a selection of new tools at your disposal, such as mines and flares - the latter of which you will absolutely need, as some parts of the game can be far too dark to move around in. It's possible this is an issue on my end, or it may just be part of the game. If it's the game itself, it is one of the very few problems introduced with this installment.

Also introduced, however, is a map. Though not always very helpful, it is often an invaluable tool, showing varied degrees of detail depending on the level and keeping track of where you've been and where you currently are.

While the final level is complicated and confusing, most of the rest of the game is a blast. One particular element of note is the interesting play on the penultimate levels of Thief Gold. Where in TG, the three levels leading up to the final one were repeat visits to locations you had already been in previous levels, in T2 the fourth-to-last level is ALSO a repeat visit to a location you had already been in Thief Gold, now taken over by the Mechanists. The next-to-last mission is, in fact, the same location as the third-to-last mission, which somehow manages to stay fresh and fun through both levels.

In the end, I heavily recommend Thief II if you enjoy stealth games. If you played Thief Gold but only sometimes liked it, I ask that you give Thief II a try instead, as it has ironed out most of the kinks. The only other thing I would like to note is that, like TFix for TG, Thief II is at its best when Tafferpatcher (a fan-made patch which improves resolution, textures, compatibility, etc.) has been applied.

Now get thieving, you dirty taffer.

After finishing System Shock 2 in 1999, The geniuses at Looking Glass Studios would set out to create a sequel to their most successful franchise. It would sadly be their last ever game as financial problems would see the studio close 2 months later.

Thief 2 is everything you could possibly ask for in a sequel; tighter and much larger level design, deeper exploration of the characters, a tighter and a more coherent atmosphere and an enthralling story of an unlikely alliance solving a twisting and evolving mystery that threatens to destroy The City and beyond.

Once again, Garrett is the unlikely hero of the tale. Stealing to survive and slinking through the shadows are a daily fact of life for him; Getting to the truth, whilst stopping to line his pockets along the way.

You'll be exploring nobleman's estates, police stations, banks, cathedrals and even The Thieves' Highway. All the while, the atmosphere and storytelling will keep you on your toes and keep your mind sharp. The environments in Thief 2 are much bigger and much more detailed than the first game and gone are the vast majority of undead, haunted crypts and tombs the first game contained. 

You'll also have some new gear to play with in Thief 2; Slow-fall potions, expensive and rare invisibility potions, flash mines and 'The Eye', which I won't go into much detail about, as well as others.

Thief 2 is also more challenging than the first game. Higher difficulty levels will, in some cases, require you to leave very little or, in one case, zero trace of your presence behind in one or two levels. This will require you to think ahead even more about what to expect; a tense but rewarding experience.

This game the peak of the Thief series so far, the graphics are much improved over the first game and the story, whilst having a satisfying conclusion, left the door wide open for a Thief 3 that would never arrive from the studio that started it all.

So Adiós Looking Glass. You created amazing experiences, stories and gameplay long before it was the norm in gaming as we know it today and even now, studios are still playing catchup to you.

The game is very mod friendly. You can find texture packs and graphical upgrades out there. If you need help setting up the game, you can read this guide here:

Obviously, I'm going to recommend the hell out of this game if you want a gaming experience that will live long in the memory!

Calling Thief II the best stealth game I've ever played is an understatement. Thief II is quite simply the best game I've ever played, period, and is my go-to example of how to do game design right.

While it's old, ugly and more than a little cheesy, the game is thoughtfully and brilliantly designed. Every element has a reason to be there, its level design is simply the best I've even seen in a game, and despite having logged well over a hundred hours in it across various playthroughs I still find new surprises in familiar haunts. Thief II isn't big in the Witcher 3, "here's 50 square miles of monster-filled backwoods with no real reason to look around" sort of way. It's big in the way your neighborhood was big when you were a kid. You live here. You know this place. But somehow here's something you've never seen before.

On the gameplay side of things, Thief II is simply a lot more fair than most stealth games, which often seem deliberately designed to make you screw up, via twitchy paranoid guards, bottlenecking level design, or random arbitrary rule changes. Thief does none of that, and every time I get caught it genuinely feels like an error on my part and not because the AI randomly decided to spin around right as the blackjack was about to hit the back of their head. Hiding in shadows actually works, the levels are expansive enough that guard patrols take more than five seconds to loop back around, and there is very rarely only one way in.

Fans of stealth games and students of game design as an art form would both do well to give this game a look.

Thief II is the gold standard upon which all stealth games/games with stealth mechanics are to be evaluated. The original Thief was treading into unknown territory and hedged its bets with more action/horror/Tomb Raiderish levels against mostly nonverbal inhuman foes. Thief II is straight up robbing human establishments against foes that you can always understand just how alerted to your presence they are. Light & shadow are integral to going undetected, but it's sound that you'll be relying upon more than sight.

You'll spend lots of time just standing still, just listening and watching, waiting to move. You're constantly under-supplied, and there's no point in hoarding inventory since it doesn't carry over between levels. Fighting won't end well. On Hard you're not even PERMITTED to kill. Escaping once detected isn't easy. Your maps are vague & incomplete. All that is what makes your victories that much more satisfying.

Modern AAA gaming will never permit this experience ever again.
